questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a well-child examination. He has cystic fibrosis diagnosed by newborn screening. His parents report frequent feedings and large-volume, greasy stools. Current medications include bronchodilators, pancreatic enzyme supplements, and fat-soluble vitamins. He is at the 18th percentile for height and 15th percentile for weight. Auscultation of the lungs discloses diffuse wheezes. Examination shows a distended and tympanic abdomen with no tenderness or guarding. Which of the following would be a contraindication for administering one or more routine vaccinations in this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Developing a fever after vaccination is not a contraindication for subsequent vaccinations. Although developing a fever of ≥ 40.5°C (105.0°F) within 48 hours of receiving DTaP was previously a contraindication for subsequent DTaP vaccinations, it is now considered safe to administer the vaccine. Moderate to severe acute illness, with or without fever at the time of vaccination, is a precaution rather than a contraindication for most vaccines.

B) INCORRECT:

Cystic fibrosis is not a contraindication for any vaccines. If possible, patients with cystic fibrosis should always be up-to-date with their vaccinations to prevent complications.

C) INCORRECT:

A history of severe allergic reaction (i.e., anaphylaxis) to a previous dose of the vaccine or any of its components is a contraindication for any particular vaccine. However, a history of egg protein allergy without severe reaction to a vaccine is not a contraindication for egg protein-containing vaccines (e.g., flu vaccine) according to the Centers for Disease Control. Moreover, none of the routine immunizations scheduled at 4 months (rotavirus, DTaP, Hib, PCV, and IPV) contain egg proteins.

D) INCORRECT:

Certain unstable neurological disorders (e.g., uncontrolled epilepsy, infantile spasms, progressive encephalopathy) are contraindications for the pertussis vaccine, which is part of the DTaP vaccine. However, neither stable neurological disorders (e.g., controlled epilepsy), nor resolved neurological disorders, nor a history of uncomplicated febrile seizures are contraindications for any of the standard childhood vaccines.

E) CORRECT:

Individuals with cystic fibrosis are at increased risk of developing intussusception. Although data is conflicting, a history of intussusception is considered a contraindication for receiving the rotavirus vaccine according to the Centers for Disease Control (CDC). The exact mechanism by which the rotavirus vaccine leads to intussusception is unknown. Some studies suggest that since the introduction of the rotavirus vaccine the overall incidence of intussusception has not risen but the average age of onset in infants has decreased.

According to the CDC, other contraindications to the rotavirus vaccine are severe combined immunodeficiency and severe allergic reactions (i.e., anaphylaxis) to a previous dose of the vaccine.
questions.hint: This 4-month-old patient should receive his routine immunizations, including diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, acellular pertussis (DTaP), Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), inactivated poliovirus (IPV), pneumococcal conjugate, and rotavirus vaccines, the latter of which is contraindicated by one of the conditions listed below.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman comes to the emergency department for a 1-week history of jaundice and nausea. She recalls eating some seafood last weekend at a cookout. She lives at home with her 4-year-old son who attends a daycare center. The child's immunizations are up-to-date. The patient's temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 134/84 mm Hg. Examination shows scleral icterus. The liver is palpated 2 cm below the right costal margin and is tender. Her serum studies show:


Total bilirubin
3.4 mg/dL


Alkaline phosphatase
119 U/L


AST
185 U/L


ALT
723 U/L


Hepatitis A IgM antibody
positive


Hepatitis B surface antibody
positive


Hepatitis B surface antigen
negative


Hepatitis B core IgM antibody
negative


Hepatitis C antibody
negative


Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate for this patient's child at this time?

choices.text: Administer hepatitis B immunoglobulin and hepatitis B vaccine
Administer hepatitis A vaccine and hepatitis A immunoglobulin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Initial administration of hepatitis B vaccine only is part of the post-exposure prophylaxis in patients with a potential percutaneous or sexual exposure to hepatitis B who were previously immunized, but whose response to immunization is unknown. While hepatitis B infection can present with nausea, jaundice, hyperbilirubinemia, and transaminitis, this patient has confirmed HBV immunity (surface antigen and anti-core antibody negative, anti-surface antigen positive). Instead, her positive hepatitis A IgM antibody indicates acute hepatitis A infection. Additionally, her son has no history of exposure to bodily fluids from the mother, so he is not at risk of HBV infection regardless. Furthermore, the 4-year-old child has already received all age-appropriate vaccines, which includes the hepatitis B vaccine.

B) INCORRECT:

Administration of both hepatitis B immunoglobulin and vaccine is the preferred post-exposure prophylaxis for unvaccinated individuals or patients who have been incompletely immunized. While hepatitis B infection can present with nausea, jaundice, hyperbilirubinemia, and transaminitis, this patient has confirmed HBV immunity (surface antigen and anti-core antibody negative, anti-surface antigen positive). Instead, her positive hepatitis A IgM antibody indicates acute hepatitis A infection. Additionally, her son has no history of exposure to bodily fluids from the mother, so he is not at risk of HBV infection regardless. Furthermore, the 4-year-old child has already received all age-appropriate vaccines, which includes the hepatitis B vaccine.

C) INCORRECT:

HAV immunoglobulin alone is indicated as postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) in unvaccinated infants < 12 months old as well as individuals in whom HAV vaccination is contraindicated. Since the child is already vaccinated against hepatitis A, passive vaccination is not indicated. This 4-year-old child's vaccinations, including the HAV vaccine, are up to date, and thus, no PEP is indicated at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Isolation is not recommended when hepatitis A is diagnosed. Also, this child is vaccinated and unlikely to be infected and thus unlikely to infect others. Since hepatitis A is spread by the fecal-oral route, good hygiene (especially hand washing) is routinely recommended.

E) CORRECT:

According to the CDC, routine vaccination against HAV, which consists of a series of two shots (with the second being administered 6–18 months after the first), is recommended for all children > 12 months of age in the US. Because this child's immunizations are up-to-date (including the HAV vaccine), he does not require postexposure prophylaxis. Current guidelines do not recommend HAV booster vaccination after successful primary immunization, as it confers long-term immunity.

F) INCORRECT:

HAV vaccine is indicated as postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) in previously unvaccinated children ≥ 12 months of age and adults who are immunocompetent and have no history of chronic liver disease. Because this 4-year-old child's vaccinations (including the HAV vaccine) are up to date, PEP is not indicated at this time.

G) INCORRECT:

Administration of hepatitis B immunoglobulin is part of the post-exposure prophylaxis for unvaccinated individuals or patients who have been incompletely immunized. However, administration of hepatitis B immunoglobulin alone is an incomplete regimen as it only provides passive immunity. While hepatitis B infection can present with nausea, jaundice, hyperbilirubinemia, and transaminitis, this patient has confirmed HBV immunity (surface antigen and anti-core antibody negative, anti-surface antigen positive). Instead, her positive hepatitis A IgM antibody indicates acute hepatitis A infection. Additionally, her son has no history of exposure to bodily fluids from the mother, so he is not at risk of HBV infection regardless.

H) INCORRECT:

The combination of the HAV vaccine and immunoglobulin is indicated as postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) in HAV-exposed children ≥ 12 months and adults who are immunocompromised, have chronic liver disease, or have not been previously vaccinated. This 4-year-old child's vaccinations, including the HAV vaccine, are up to date, and therefore, no PEP is indicated at this time.
questions.hint: The patient has jaundice, fever, nausea, a history of eating seafood, and positive hepatitis A IgM antibodies all indicating acute hepatitis A (HAV) infection. Her 4-year-old child has already received all age-appropriate vaccines.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician in June for a routine check-up. She has chronic back pain and underwent an appendectomy at the age of 27. Her last mammogram was 6 months ago and showed no abnormalities. Her last Pap smear was 2 years ago and unremarkable. A colonoscopy 5 years ago was normal. She regularly attends water aerobic classes and physical therapy for her back pain. Her mother died of breast cancer last year and her father has arterial hypertension. She is married and has two children. The patient recently got back from a cruise to Mexico where she celebrated her 40th wedding anniversary. She takes a multivitamin daily and uses topical steroids. Her immunization records show that she has never received a pneumococcal or a shingles vaccine, her last tetanus booster was 6 years ago, and her last influenza vaccine was 2 years ago. She drinks one to two alcoholic beverages every weekend. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 72 kg (160 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 124/70 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis screening is performed with dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA). The bone density scan is recommended for postmenopausal women older than 65 years of age, or younger postmenopausal women with a pathological fracture or other risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., positive family history).

B) INCORRECT:

The CDC recommends pneumococcal vaccination for adults ≥ 50 years of age. However, the polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) is typically recommended after administering a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, which this patient has not yet received.

C) INCORRECT:

The US Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). A colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had her last colonoscopy 5 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), a colonoscopy is not indicated at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

A Pap smear is recommended every 3 years in women 21–65 years of age (or even better for patients 30–65 years of age, HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years). This woman had a normal Pap smear 2 years ago.

E) INCORRECT:

Because influenza viruses are constantly evolving, the influenza vaccine composition is reviewed, and a newly updated vaccine is released (and recommended) for every flu season (∼ Oct.–Apr. in the northern hemisphere). This patient should return again in the early fall for an influenza vaccine.

F) CORRECT:

The CDC currently recommends the recombinant zoster vaccine for the prevention of herpes zoster (shingles) and its related complications. The recombinant zoster vaccine (administered in 2 doses, 2–6 months apart) is recommended for all immunocompetent adults ≥ 50 years of age, regardless of a history of shingles, and for adults ≥ 19 years of age who are or will become immunodeficient or immunosuppressed due to disease or therapy.

Additionally, this individual should receive pneumococcal vaccination with a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine.
questions.hint: The correct choice is recommended in all patients over 50 years by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 0, at 28 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a prenatal visit. She has not had regular prenatal care. Her most recent ultrasound at 20 weeks of gestation confirmed accurate fetal dates and appropriate fetal development. She takes levothyroxine for hypothyroidism. She used to work as a nurse before she emigrated from Brazil 13 years ago. She lost her immunization records during the move and cannot recall all of her vaccinations. She appears well. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a fundal height of 26 cm and no abnormalities. An ELISA test for HIV is negative. Serology testing for hepatitis B surface antibody and hepatitis C antibody are both positive. Hepatitis B core antibody, hepatitis B surface antigen, and hepatitis A antibody are negative. Polymerase chain reaction of hepatitis C RNA is positive for genotype 1. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?

choices.text: Start combination therapy with ledipasvir/sofosbuvir and ribavirin
Start combination therapy with interferon α and ribavirin
Plan to formula feed the newborn
Plan to give hepatitis B vaccine and hepatitis B Ig to the newborn

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Combination therapy with ledipasvir/sofosbuvir and ribavirin is indicated in patients with chronic hepatitis C infection. However, ribavirin has known teratogenic effects and ledipasvir/sofosbuvir combination should only be used if the benefits outweigh the risks. None of these drugs are proven to prevent the vertical transmission of the virus to the fetus.

After giving birth, this woman should be put on antiviral medication to treat her hepatitis C infection. As she is infected with genotype 1, she could be treated with two direct-acting antivirals like ledipasvir and sofosbuvir.

B) INCORRECT:

Individuals who are HCV-positive usually receive combination treatment with ribavirin and interferons such as interferon α. However, ribavirin has known teratogenic effects on the fetus and interferons have been shown to cause abortion in animal models. Therefore, combination antiviral therapy is not recommended in this pregnant women infected with HCV.

C) INCORRECT:

Formula as a substitute for breast milk may be indicated if the mother has an active infection such as herpetic lesions on the breast, if she is undergoing chemotherapy, or if the baby has galactosemia. Hepatitis C does not spread via breast milk, so breastfeeding is not contraindicated.

D) CORRECT:

Individuals with chronic liver disease such as hepatitis C can develop liver failure if infected with hepatitis A. It is imperative that this pregnant patient, who has chronic hepatitis C infection and has been vaccinated against hepatitis B but not against hepatitis A (no anti-HAV IgG antibodies), receives the hepatitis A vaccine to prevent such complications.

E) INCORRECT:

This woman has chronic hepatitis C. There is an approximately 4% risk of vertical transmission of the virus. However, cesarean delivery has not been shown to prevent or reduce vertical transmission of HCV. Cesarean deliveries are used to reduce transmission in, e.g., HIV-positive patients (unless viral load is very low) and those with active genital herpes.

F) INCORRECT:

Newborns are given the hepatitis B vaccine and immunoglobulin if the mother has an active hepatitis B infection. However, the positive hepatitis B surface antibody and the negative core and surface antigens indicate the woman has already been vaccinated against hepatitis B. If she were infected, the hepatitis B surface antigen would be positive. Therefore, her newborn does not need hepatitis B immunoglobulin but will require vaccination against hepatitis B in accordance with the immunization schedule.
questions.hint: This pregnant patient has a positive hepatitis C antibody and is hepatitis C RNA positive, indicating chronic liver disease due to an active hepatitis C infection. The presence of the hepatitis B surface antibody and absence of hepatitis core and surface antigens indicate she has immunity acquired by vaccination.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician in May for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He underwent right inguinal hernia repair 6 months ago. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. There is no family history of serious illness. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, enalapril, and metoprolol. He received the zoster vaccine 1 year ago. His last colonoscopy 7 years ago showed no abnormalities. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 9 years. He drinks two to three alcoholic beverages on weekends. He is allergic to amoxicillin. He lives in Seattle and is scheduled to visit Australia and New Zealand in 2 weeks to celebrate his 25th wedding anniversary. He appears healthy. Vital signs are within normal limits. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?

choices.text: Low-dose CT scan of the chest

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A low-dose CT scan of the chest may be used to screen for lung cancer. Most societies recommend an annual low-dose CT scan for active smokers 50–80 years of age who have a 20 pack-year or longer smoking history. This patient has an 18 pack-year smoking history.

B) CORRECT:

The influenza vaccine (either live-attenuated or inactivated) is recommended every year during flu season, from October to April in the northern hemisphere and April to October in the southern hemisphere. The composition of each vaccine is adjusted for the hemisphere in which it is given, which may not always be antigenically identical. Despite providing only partial immunity in these cases, the influenza vaccine in the northern hemisphere typically provides protection against the main viruses that are circulating in other parts of the world. Therefore, vaccination of patients who have not received the influenza vaccine during the influenza season is recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, and World Health Organization at least 2 weeks prior to travel. Although a US-licensed influenza vaccine for the southern hemisphere can be given to patients prior to travel, it is generally not commercially available and the vaccine for the northern hemisphere is used.

C) INCORRECT:

A dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan may be performed to screen for osteoporosis. In patients with no other risk factors, a DEXA scan is recommended for women at 65 years of age. However, the United States Preventive Services Task Force does not currently recommend screening for osteoporosis to prevent osteoporotic fractures in men. In addition, this patient does not have any risk factors (e.g., corticosteroid use, history of heavy drinking) or previous history (e.g., bone fracture following minor trauma) to suggest osteoporosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Abdominal ultrasonography may be performed to screen for abdominal aortic aneurysm in men 65–75 years of age who are or were smokers. This patient should undergo an abdominal ultrasound in 3 years, but it is not indicated at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

The United States Preventive Services Task Force recommends screening for colorectal cancer in all asymptomatic adults between 45 and 75 years of age who have an average risk (e.g., no inflammatory bowel disease, adenomatous polyps, or family history of an inherited cancer syndrome). The previously recommended age to start screening was 50 years. Colonoscopy every 10 years is an appropriate strategy. Because this patient had his last colonoscopy 7 years ago, which was normal, and lacks symptoms suggestive of colorectal cancer (e.g., weight loss, hematochezia), a colonoscopy is not indicated at this time.

F) INCORRECT:

A cardiac stress test evaluates how the heart responds to physical stress. Indications for cardiac stress testing include chronic stable angina and exertional symptoms (e.g., palpitations, syncope), none of which this patient has. Cardiac evaluation may also be indicated for patients with risk factors for cardiovascular disease (e.g., diabetes mellitus, hypertension). However, routine studies (e.g., an ECG) are usually indicated before proceeding to cardiac stress testing. A different management step is more appropriate for this patient who is scheduled to visit the southern hemisphere.
questions.hint: This patient seems to be in good health overall. There is only one concern in the southern hemisphere in May: “Winter is coming.”

questions.text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician in July for a routine health maintenance examination. He is a retired teacher and lives in Nebraska, in a residential community for older adults. He has hypercholesterolemia, hypertension, and osteoarthritis of the left knee. Last year, he was diagnosed with chronic lymphocytic leukemia. A colonoscopy 8 years ago showed no abnormalities. He had chickenpox during childhood. He is up-to-date regarding vaccinations against hepatitis B, diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, measles, mumps, rubella, COVID-19, and poliovirus. He has never smoked and does not drink alcohol. Current medications include aspirin, lisinopril, simvastatin, chlorambucil, rituximab, and a multivitamin. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 82/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 133/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows painless cervical lymphadenopathy. Administration of which of the following vaccines is most appropriate at this visit?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pneumococcal vaccination is indicated for all individuals ≥ 50 years of age and those 19–49 years of age with risk factors for invasive pneumococcal disease (e.g., immunosuppression). For individuals with no prior vaccination, the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine 15 (PCV15) followed ≥ 1 year later (≥ 8 weeks should be considered in immunocompromised individuals) by the pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine 23 (PPSV23) is an appropriate option. Alternatively, this patient could be given the PCV20 or PCV21, which do not require subsequent vaccination with PPSV23. Since April 2024, PCV13 is no longer available in the US.

In addition, this patient should receive two doses of recombinant zoster vaccine. Also, because this patient has adult risk factors for severe RSV infection as well as risk factors for invasive meningococcal disease, the RSV vaccine and the meningococcal conjugate vaccine should be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

In individuals ≥ 13 years of age, the varicella vaccine is indicated if the individual has no evidence of immunity against chickenpox (e.g., prior vaccine, documented history of infection). This patient had chickenpox during childhood and, therefore, does not require varicella vaccination.

In addition to the varicella vaccine, which is used to prevent primary varicella zoster virus infection (i.e., chickenpox) and is only indicated in adults in absence of immunity, the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends a vaccine to prevent the reactivation of varicella zoster virus (i.e., shingles), regardless of any history of shingles. Shingles vaccination is recommended for all immunocompetent individuals ≥ 50 years of age and for immunocompromised individuals ≥ 19 years of age. Therefore, this patient should receive two doses of recombinant zoster vaccine (not varicella vaccine!) 2–6 months apart (if he has not already received them at his last visit). The recombinant zoster vaccine is preferred over the live zoster vaccine, which is no longer available in the US.

C) INCORRECT:

The pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine 23 (PPSV23) offers protection against several subtypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae. PPSV23 should be administered to healthy adults ≥ 50 years of age and also to immunocompromised individuals aged 19–49 years. However, this patient requires a different vaccine before receiving PPSV23.

D) INCORRECT:

Annual influenza vaccination is recommended for all individuals ≥ 6 months of age who do not have contraindications at the start of the flu season, which begins near the end of October (in the Northern Hemisphere). This patient has come for his routine health maintenance examination in July.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient is ≥ 65 years of age and immunocompromised, both of which are indications for a specific vaccine.

questions.text: A 1550-g (3.3-lb) male newborn is delivered to a 26-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 2, at 33 weeks' gestation. Apgar scores are 7 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The pregnancy was complicated by iron deficiency anemia. The mother has no other history of serious illness and she received all routine immunizations. She has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years. She does not drink alcohol. She has never used illicit drugs. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were complicated by placenta previa. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation regarding immunization for this newborn?

choices.text: Rotavirus vaccine at 3 months of chronological age
Measles, mumps, rubella vaccine at 2 months of chronological age
Inactivated poliovirus vaccine at 3 months of chronological age
Haemophilus influenza type b vaccine at 3 months of chronological age
Diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine at 2 months of chronological age

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The rotavirus vaccine is given as a 2-dose or 3-dose regimen, depending upon the vaccine used. The first dose is given at 2 months, the second dose at 4 months, and the last dose at 6 months (if needed). This preterm infant should not wait until 3 months (≈ 5 weeks prematurity + 2 months) to get the first dose of the rotavirus vaccine.

B) INCORRECT:

This is a good option to consider, but it is incorrect because of one detail - the patient's weight! According to the CDC, the hepatitis B vaccine is typically given as a 3-dose regimen, with the first dose administered at birth, the second dose at 1–2 months, and the third dose at 6–18 months of age in children whose mothers are HbsAg-negative, such as this newborn's fully-immunized mother. However, infants with low birth weight have weak production of protective anti-HBs antibodies, so newborns < 2000 g should receive their first dose at 1 month of age (regardless of weight at that time) or upon discharge from the hospital, whichever comes sooner. This newborn currently weighs 1550-g (3.3-lb), so hepatitis B vaccine administration would not be recommended at this time.

C) INCORRECT:

The measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) vaccine is usually administered as a 2-dose regimen, with the first dose at 12–15 months of age and the second dose at 4–6 years of age. This preterm infant needs to be at least 12 months of age to receive the MMR vaccine.

D) INCORRECT:

The inactivated poliovirus vaccine (IPV) is usually given as a 3-dose regimen, with the first dose at 2 months, the second dose at 4 months, and the last dose at 6–18 months. A booster dose should be given at 4–6 years of age. This preterm infant should not wait until 3 months (≈ 5 weeks prematurity + 2 months) to get the first dose of IPV.

E) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine is a polysaccharide-protein conjugate vaccine used in infants to prevent meningitis, pneumonia, and epiglottitis caused by Hib. It is usually given as a 3-dose regimen, with the first dose at 2 months, the second dose at 4 months, and the last dose at 6 months. A booster dose should be given at 12–15 months. This preterm infant should not wait 3 months (≈ 5 weeks prematurity + 2 months) to get the first dose of the Hib vaccine.

F) CORRECT:

The diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine is given to children < 7 years of age as a 5-dose regimen at 2, 4, 6, 15–18 months, and 4–6 years of age, respectively. This preterm infant has no indications that would delay the DTaP vaccine, such as uncontrolled seizures or nervous system disease, and can receive the vaccine at 2 months of chronological age.

Note that the Hepatitis B vaccine would be given before the DTaP vaccine but not immediately after birth, which is the standard immunization schedule for term newborns > 2000 g of birth weight. Infants with low birth weight have weak production of protective anti-HBs antibodies, so newborns < 2000 g should receive their first dose of Hepatitis B vaccine at 1 month of age (regardless of weight at that time) or upon discharge from the hospital, whichever comes sooner. All other vaccines are administered according to the standard immunization schedule, taking the infant's chronological age into account, irrespective of prematurity.
questions.hint: Preterm infants are to receive all recommended vaccinations as per their chronological age (the time elapsed after birth) unless contraindicated. Gestational age does not play a role in determining the timing of the regimen.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old primigravid woman comes to the physician in October for her first prenatal visit. She has delayed the visit because she wanted a “natural birth” but was recently convinced to get a checkup after feeling more tired than usual. She feels well. Menarche was at the age of 12 years and menses used to occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 3–7 days. The patient emigrated from Mexico 2 years ago. Her immunization records are unavailable. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 28-week gestation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12.4 g/dL


Leukocyte count
8000/mm3



Blood group
B negative


Serum



 Glucose
88 mg/dL


 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL


 TSH
3.6 μU/mL


 Rapid plasma reagin
negative


 HIV antibody
negative


 Hepatitis B surface antigen
negative


Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Urine culture is negative. Chlamydia and gonorrhea testing are negative. A Pap smear shows no abnormalities. Administration of which of the following vaccines is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) vaccine is not indicated in this patient because she does not have any of the risk factors for which Hib vaccine is normally indicated (e.g., asplenia). The Hib vaccine is not routinely recommended during pregnancy.

B) CORRECT:

All pregnant individuals should receive a single dose of Tdap between the 27th and 36th weeks of pregnancy. Tdap vaccine protects the mother from puerperal tetanus and the neonate from pertussis, diphtheria, and neonatal tetanus. The injectable (inactivated) form of the influenza vaccine is also indicated in pregnant individuals because an influenza infection during pregnancy is associated with a more severe infection and a higher risk of both preterm labor and fetal defects. The influenza vaccine is safe during all trimesters and should ideally be administered by the end of October (i.e., prior to the onset of the flu season, which lasts from October until May) and protects the mother and the neonate from influenza infection for up to several months after the delivery. A live, attenuated, nasal spray vaccine is also available, but only the injectable forms of the influenza vaccine should be used in this patient because live vaccines are contraindicated during pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

The mumps, measles, and rubella (MMR) vaccine is a live vaccine and therefore contraindicated during pregnancy.

D) INCORRECT:

The human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine is not recommended during pregnancy because the effects of the vaccine on the fetus are not fully understood.

E) INCORRECT:

The influenza vaccine is indicated for pregnant individuals because an influenza infection during pregnancy is associated with a more severe infection (e.g., pneumonia) and a higher risk of both preterm labor and fetal defects. However, in a patient at 28 weeks' gestation, another immunization should also be administered.
questions.hint: Live vaccinations are contraindicated during pregnancy.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of genital lesions. She has no history of serious illness. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules over the vulva. The lesions turn white on application of 3% acetic acid. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although condom use may help reduce the risk of HPV transmission, studies have shown that contact with uncovered areas still allows for HPV transmission. Condom use is therefore not the best option for preventing this patient's condition.

B) INCORRECT:

HIV can present with genital lesions in a sexually active individual. Molluscum contagiosum, which is a common genital lesion in adults associated with HIV, could present with a nontender, exophytic papule on the genitalia. However, these lesions would have a characteristic hemispherical, umbilicated appearance, and they would not turn white on application of 3% acetic acid. Moreover, there are no other features in this patient that suggest immunocompromise, which is typical of HIV.

C) INCORRECT:

Spermicidal foams and gels are means of contraception with medium efficacy and may be used by sexually active individuals who do not intend to get pregnant. However, they do not provide any protection against sexually transmitted infections, such as the one in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Famciclovir is used for the treatment and prophylaxis of genital herpes caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV-1 or HSV-2). A case of genital herpes could present with multiple raised lesions over the vulva. However, the lesions would be vesicular or ulcerative, very painful, and associated with systemic features (like fever, lymphadenopathy, etc.), which are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patient

Fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.

These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with condylomata acuminata, which are genital warts caused by HPV. HPV vaccines are recommended by the CDC to all persons aged 9–26 years and are most effective before exposure to HPV via sexual activity; they are routinely administered at 11–12 years of age. The tetravalent and 9-valent vaccines provide ∼ 99% coverage against the types of HPV most commonly implicated in genital warts (types 6 and 11) and in cervical cancer (especially types 16 and 18) for at least 10 years after vaccination (likely longer, but data is only available for that time period). Given this patient's sexual history, HPV vaccine would most likely have prevented this condition.

Some older HPV vaccines (e.g., Cervarix®) do not cover the types of HPV associated with genital warts (types 6 and 11) and only protect against cervical cancer.
Image Description:

Photograph of the perianal region of a child with HIV (image rotated: gluteal cleft runs from upper right to lower left of image)

Multiple flesh-colored papules with a folded irregular surface have formed a plaque in the perianal region.

Immunodeficiency (e.g., due to HIV infection) increases both the risk of HPV infection becoming symptomatic (in this case with anogenital warts) and the severity of symptoms
questions.hint: In a sexually active adolescent, the presence of multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules indicates human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician for a routine pelvic examination. She feels well. Menses occur at 30-day intervals and last 7 days. Her last menstrual period was 6 days ago. Her last Pap smear was 13 months ago and there is no history of abnormal findings. She is sexually active with three male partners and uses condoms consistently. She has never been tested for sexually transmitted infections. Her 54-year-old mother has breast cancer. She did not receive a human papillomavirus vaccine. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 68/min, and blood pressure is 108/68 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis testing, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

As part of the routine immunization schedule, the CDC states that two doses of the nine-valent human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine should be administered six to twelve months apart to all individuals aged 9–14 years. For all unvaccinated female individuals aged 15–26 years, the CDC recommends vaccination with three doses of the nine-valent HPV vaccine at 0, 2, and 6 months. The HPV vaccine is approved by the FDA for individuals up to the age of 45 years, but it is not routinely recommended by the CDC for individuals aged > 26 years.

Condoms lower the risk of, but do not protect against, HPV infection because HPV can still be transmitted via genital skin-to-skin contact or oral sex.

B) INCORRECT:

For women aged between 21 and 29 years, the USPSTF recommends a Pap smear every three years. Since this patient had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago, another Pap smear is not required for nearly another two years.

C) INCORRECT:

The most common indication for a pregnancy test is recent-onset secondary amenorrhea in a patient of childbearing age. Because her last menstrual period was six days ago, this patient does not have amenorrhea. If this 24-year-old woman had acute lower abdominal pain, a pregnancy test would be indicated to rule out an ectopic pregnancy. However, there is currently no indication for performing a pregnancy test in this asymptomatic patient presenting for a routine pelvic examination.

D) INCORRECT:

Cotesting refers to simultaneous Pap smear and HPV testing. It is the USPSTF's recommended cervical cancer screening of choice for women aged between 30 and 65 years every five years. In this 24-year-old patient, the USPSTF instead recommends a Pap smear every three years. Unfortunately, cancer screening recommendations can be confusing because the USPSTF guidelines differ from the recently updated ASCCP/ACS/ACOG guidelines, which recommend that women aged 25–65 years should undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing (preferred where available) every five years, cotesting (HPV testing and Pap smear) every five years, or a solitary Pap smear every three years. But this patient is not yet 25 years of age and also had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago. Regardless, if the information required to determine the correct option for NBME questions is associated with a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF guidelines.

E) INCORRECT:

HPV testing and a simultaneous Pap smear, known as cotesting, is recommended by the USPSTF for cervical cancer screening for patients aged 30–65 years every five years. Unfortunately, cancer screening recommendations can be confusing because the USPSTF guidelines differ from the recently updated ASCCP/ACS/ACOG guidelines, which recommend women aged 25–65 years should undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing alone (preferred where available) every five years, cotesting (HPV testing and Pap smear) every five years, or a solitary Pap smear every three years. But this patient is not yet 25 years of age and also had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago. Regardless, if the information required to determine the correct option for NBME questions is associated with a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF guidelines.
questions.hint: This patient's history and age determine the most appropriate recommendation at this time.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He was diagnosed with HIV 8 years ago. He is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. He is sexually active and uses condoms consistently. He is planning a trip to Thailand with his partner to celebrate his 35th birthday in 6 weeks. His last tetanus and diphtheria booster was given 4 years ago. He received three vaccinations against hepatitis B 5 years ago. He had chickenpox as a child. Other immunization records are unknown. Vital signs are within normal limits. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. His leukocyte count is 8700/mm3, CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 480 cells/mm3, and anti-HBs antibody titer is 150 mIU/mL. Which of the following recommendations is most appropriate at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Hepatitis B vaccine is generally recommended for all HIV-positive patients without immunity to hepatitis B. A booster dose following previous vaccination is required if the anti-HBs titer is < 10 mlU/mL. Since this patient's anti-HBs titer is 150 mlU/mL, he still has adequate immunity to hepatitis B.

B) INCORRECT:

The Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) live vaccine is given to select patient groups (e.g., children with a negative tuberculin skin test and continued high-risk exposure, healthcare workers on an individual basis) to prevent TB infection. However, it is no longer generally recommended in the US because of its variable effectiveness and the overall low risk of infection with Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

C) INCORRECT:

In adults with a completed routine tetanus and diphtheria vaccination, booster doses are recommended every 10 years. In cases of injury with an increased risk of tetanus infection (e.g., animal bites), a booster dose is administered if the last immunization was ≥ 5 years ago. Since this patient's tetanus and diphtheria vaccination are up-to-date, no further boost is required at this point.

D) CORRECT:

Vaccinations in individuals infected with HIV should follow the generally recommended immunization schedule, including for live vaccines. Adults with uncertain immunity to measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) such as those with unknown vaccination status, no laboratory evidence of immunity, or born after 1957, should be given a dose of MMR vaccine, provided the CD4+ count is > 200 cells/mm3. Further recommendations for patients with HIV include vaccinations for pneumococcal disease and influenza (using the inactivated or recombinant influenza vaccines, as the live-attenuated vaccine is not recommended regardless of CD4+ count). The efficacy of immunization is reduced in patients with HIV infection.

E) INCORRECT:

The yellow fever vaccine should be administered to individuals traveling to endemic areas, including tropical Africa (e.g, Guinea, Ghana) and parts of Central and South America (e.g., Brazil, Ecuador). While live vaccines like the yellow fever vaccine can be safely administered in HIV patients with a CD4+ count > 200 cells/mm3 and no signs of immunocompromise (e.g., presence of AIDS-defining illness), yellow fever is not endemic in Thailand.
Image Description:

The green areas indicate regions where yellow fever is endemic. The WHO recommends vaccination for travelers to high-risk areas. When traveling to low-risk areas, there is no general recommendation; however, vaccination may be considered for longer stays or if there is a high risk of exposure. Proof of vaccination may be required when traveling to or from certain countries. Consult information from the WHO or CDC before traveling.

F) INCORRECT:

The standard immunization schedule should generally be observed in patients with HIV. Exceptions to this rule include a CD4 count < 200 cells/mm3 and the presence of AIDS-defining illnesses (e.g., Kaposi sarcoma, pneumocystis pneumonia). Since none of these exceptions are present, this patient should receive the generally recommended vaccinations.
questions.hint: The immunization schedule including live attenuated vaccines fully applies to patients with HIV infection and a CD4+ count above 200 cells/mm3.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician in June for a follow-up examination after being diagnosed with HIV infection 3 months ago. He has been taking combined antiretroviral therapy since then. He feels well. He is sexually active with both female and male partners and regularly uses barrier protection. He does not smoke and drinks 2–3 glasses of wine on weekends. The patient did not receive any childhood vaccines besides the hepatitis B vaccine. Six years ago, he received the tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccination. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. His CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count is 190/mm3. Which of the following immunizations should be administered at this time?

choices.text: Tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis vaccine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vaccination against varicella requires the administration of a live attenuated vaccine. Live vaccines should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals such as this patient, who has a CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count < 200/mm3. Once his CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count is > 200/mm3, he should receive this vaccine to protect him against chickenpox and shingles.

B) INCORRECT:

The tetanus toxoid, diphtheria toxoid, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccination is indicated in adults who did not receive the usual schedule of vaccinations during childhood, as is the case in this patient. Booster vaccination with tetanus and diphtheria toxoids (Td) is required every 10 years in order to maintain full immunity. However, this patient received his Tdap vaccine only 6 years ago, which means that he will not require a booster dose of the Td vaccine for another 4 years.

C) INCORRECT:

Annual Influenza vaccination with the inactivated or recombinant vaccine is highly recommended, especially in immunocompromised individuals such as this patient. However, he is currently being seen in the month of June, which is still too early for the influenza vaccine. For maximum protection from the influenza virus, he should receive the vaccine at a follow-up visit in the early fall. The live-attenuated influenza vaccine should not be administered to individuals with HIV infection, regardless of their CD4+ T lymphocyte count.

D) INCORRECT:

Vaccination against measles, mumps, and rubella requires the administration of a live attenuated vaccine. Live attenuated vaccines should not be administered to immunocompromised individuals such as this patient, who has a CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count of < 200/mm3. Once his CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count is > 200/mm3, he should receive this vaccine.

E) INCORRECT:

Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk for infection, including with human papillomavirus (HPV). However, the same guidelines apply to immunocompromised individuals as the general population, which is that HPV vaccination is recommended in all individuals ≤ 26 years of age. While the FDA has approved the HPV vaccine for individuals up to 45 years of age, the decision to receive a vaccine after 26 years of age is established on an individual basis.

F) INCORRECT:

Pneumococcal polysaccharide 23 vaccine (PPSV23) is recommended for individuals aged 19–65 years who are immunocompromised (e.g., those with HIV). However, the PPSV23 vaccine should not be administered before the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, PCV15. Because this patient's vaccination history is unknown, he should receive the PCV15 now and return in at least 8 weeks to receive the PPSV23. Alternatively, individuals can be given one dose of the pneumococcal conjugate vaccine PCV20 without subsequent need for PPSV23.

G) CORRECT:

Patients with HIV infection or chronic liver disease are at increased risk of developing a severe disease following infection with the hepatitis A (HepA) virus. The HepA vaccine is part of the routine vaccine regimen and is recommended for all individuals between 12 and 23 months of age with a second dose administered at least 6 months later. Any adult who did not receive the vaccine and is at high risk for HepA infection or severe disease should be vaccinated. The HepA vaccine is a killed vaccine and can be safely administered even if the patient has a low CD4 T-cell count.

Risk factors for HepA infection include recent travel to an area where the virus is endemic, recreational drug use, and men who have sex with men.
questions.hint: Special attention should be paid to the selection of appropriate vaccinations in patients with HIV, especially those with a low CD4 count, which indicates severe immunodeficiency.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with HIV infection comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She has been inconsistently taking combined antiretroviral therapy for the past 5 years. She did not receive any childhood vaccinations because her parents were against them. During the consultation, the patient says that she wants to catch up on the missed vaccinations. Laboratory studies show a CD4+ T lymphocyte cell count of 180/mm3. Administration of which of the following vaccines should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The vaccine against Bordetella pertussis is an inactivated vaccine. A CD4 count < 200/mm3 is not a contraindication for inactivated vaccines.

B) INCORRECT:

The vaccine against Human papillomavirus (HPV) is an inactivated vaccine. One of the main benefits of vaccination is protection against HPV-associated cervical cancer. HPV immunization is approved for individuals 11–26 years of age. Patients with HIV should receive HPV immunization during this same interval. A CD4 count < 200/mm3 is not a contraindication for inactivated vaccines.

C) INCORRECT:

The vaccine against Haemophilus influenzae (Hib vaccine) is an inactivated vaccine that prevents invasive infection with H. influenzae type b (Hib). A CD4 count < 200/mm3 is not a contraindication for inactivated vaccines.

D) INCORRECT:

The vaccine against Hepatitis B virus is an inactivated vaccine. A CD4 count < 200/mm3 is not a contraindication for inactivated vaccines. In fact, it is strongly recommended that patients with HIV receive the hepatitis B vaccination because of the elevated risk of chronic infection in this patient group.

E) INCORRECT:

The vaccine against Clostridium tetani is a toxoid vaccine (inactivated vaccine). A CD4 count < 200/mm3 is not a contraindication for toxoid-based immunization.

F) CORRECT:

The vaccine against varicella zoster virus is a live attenuated vaccine. It is recommended in HIV patients with a CD4 count > 200/mm3. However, a CD4 count of 180/mm3, as seen in this patient, is a contraindication for live vaccines (such as varicella, yellow fever, mumps, measles, and rubella) because of the risk of vaccine-related reactivation of the attenuated virus.
questions.hint: Live attenuated vaccines should be avoided in patients with HIV infection and a CD4 count < 200/mm3.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the physician for preconception counseling. She reports that she has been trying to conceive with her husband for 2 months. She has been in a monogamous relationship for 10 years. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last 4 days with normal flow. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She did not receive the MMR vaccine when she was young because of an “egg allergy.” Her vaccinations are otherwise up-to-date. Her only medication is a daily folic acid supplement. She feels well today. She is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 59 kg (130 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Temperature is 36.4°C (97.6°F), pulse is 81/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 118/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count is within the reference range. Her serum human chorionic gonadotropin concentration is 3 mIU/mL (N ≤ 5). An HIV antibody/antigen test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain rectal swab for group B streptococcus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iron supplementation (30–60 mg/day) is indicated in maternal iron deficiency anemia. Iron deficiency anemia can increase the risk of placental insufficiency and is the most common type of anemia in pregnancy. Iron supplementation is not needed if anemia is not present; this patient's complete blood count is within range.

B) CORRECT:

As part of comprehensive preconception care, physicians should assess individuals' immunization status and recommend all routine age-appropriate immunizations. Because of the risk of congenital abnormalities following infection with rubella or varicella in pregnancy, the MMR and varicella vaccines are especially recommended. In patients with no evidence of immunity to rubella (e.g., those who did not receive the MMR vaccine), rubella antibody testing should be used to screen for immunity, and vaccination should be recommended in individuals without immunity. The MMR and varicella vaccines are live vaccines, which are contraindicated during pregnancy due to the potential risk of infection in the birthing parent and consequent vertical transmission. Accordingly, conception should be avoided for 1–3 months after immunization.

In the past, administering the MMR vaccine to children with egg allergies raised concerns because of residual egg proteins in the vaccine. However, the MMR vaccine is currently considered safe for children with egg allergy.

C) INCORRECT:

Group B streptococcus (GBS) infection can cause chorioamnionitis, neonatal meningitis, sepsis, and pneumonia; vaginal and rectal swab for gram stain and culture can detect GBS. However, GBS screening is indicated at 36 0/7– 37 6/7 weeks of gestation rather than before conception.

D) INCORRECT:

Screening for chlamydia infection is recommended in all sexually active women < 25 years of age and all women who are at increased risk for a sexually transmitted infection (e.g., having more than one sex partner, using condoms inconsistently outside a mutually monogamous relationship, performing sex in exchange for money). This patient does not have any risk factors for chlamydia infection, so she does not need to be screened for it. All pregnant women should be screened for hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV, and syphilis at the initial examination (∼ 10 weeks gestation).

E) INCORRECT:

Patients who have overweight (BMI 25–29.9 kg/m2) or obesity (BMI ≥ 30 kg/m2) are at higher risk of difficulty with conception and adverse pregnancy outcomes. Women with obesity are at higher risk for hypertension, diabetes, gestational diabetes, stillbirth, and babies that are large for gestational age. This patient's BMI of 22 is normal (18.5–24.9 kg/m2), so she is not at increased risk for weight-related pregnancy complications.

F) INCORRECT:

A 1-hour oral glucose challenge test is used to screen for gestational diabetes mellitus. Potential complications of pregestational diabetes mellitus include gestational hypertension, preeclampsia, eclampsia, urinary tract infections, and fetal diabetic fetopathy. A 1-hour glucose challenge is indicated at 24–28 weeks of gestation; this patient's normal serum β-hCG concentration indicates that she is currently not pregnant. A hemoglobin A1C test would be used to detect pregestational diabetes mellitus.
questions.hint: This patient has a normal serum β-hCG concentration, which indicates that she is not currently pregnant. Many diseases increase the risk to the fetus and birthing parent. However, certain diseases can be devastating to the fetus and are ideally addressed prior to conception.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination in winter. He was last seen by the physician 12 months ago. His childhood vaccinations are up-to-date, but there is no documentation of human papillomavirus vaccination. He has no planned travel. Prior to starting college, he was appropriately vaccinated prior to living in residential dormitory housing. He has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following health maintenance recommendations is most appropriate at this time?



Influenza vaccination
Human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccination
Meningococcal ACWY vaccination
Haemophilus influenzae type B (Hib) vaccination



A
Yes
yes
yes
no


B
Yes
no
yes
no


C
Yes
yes
no
no


D
No
no
no
yes


E
No
yes
no
yes


F
Yes
yes
yes
yes
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The meningococcal ACWY vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations and is not considered at high risk for infection with Neisseria meningitidis at this time.

B) INCORRECT:

The HPV vaccine is recommended for unvaccinated persons 11–26 years of age. This patient should be offered the HPV vaccine because he does not have any documentation of having received it.

The meningococcal ACWY vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations and is not considered at high risk for infection with Neisseria meningitidis at this time.

C) CORRECT:

All individuals ≥ 6 months of age should receive an influenza vaccine every flu season. In the northern hemisphere, the flu season runs Oct–April, so this patient should be offered the influenza vaccine. Contraindications include a history of anaphylaxis to any part of the vaccine, which this patient does not have.

The HPV vaccine is recommended for all unvaccinated persons 11–26 years of age. This patient should be offered the HPV vaccine because he does not have any documentation of having received it.

The meningococcal ACWY vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations, so he has already completed two routine doses of the meningococcal ACWY vaccine. Additional doses of the meningococcal vaccine are only recommended for high-risk individuals (e.g., military recruits, first-year college students who reside in residential dormitory housing if not already vaccinated at ≥ 16 years of age; individuals with asplenia, HIV infection, complement inhibitor use, or a history of travel to high-risk countries). This patient does not have any of these risk factors.

The Hib vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations and would have already completed four routine doses of the Hib vaccine. Additional doses of the Hib vaccine are only recommended for high-risk individuals (e.g., individuals with asplenia or a history of hematopoietic stem cell transplant). This patient does not have any of these risk factors.

D) INCORRECT:

All individuals ≥ 6 months of age should receive an influenza vaccine every flu season. In the northern hemisphere, the flu season runs Oct–April, so this patient should be offered the influenza vaccine. Contraindications include a history of anaphylaxis to any part of the vaccine, which this patient does not have.

The HPV vaccine is recommended for unvaccinated persons 11–26 years of age. This patient should be offered the HPV vaccine because he does not have any documentation of having received it.

The Hib vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations and would have already completed four routine doses of the Hib vaccine. Additional doses of the Hib vaccine are only recommended for high-risk individuals (e.g., individuals with asplenia or a history of hematopoietic stem cell transplant). This patient does not have any of these risk factors.

E) INCORRECT:

All individuals ≥ 6 months of age should receive an influenza vaccine every flu season. In the northern hemisphere, the flu season runs Oct–April, so this patient should be offered the influenza vaccine. Contraindications include a history of anaphylaxis to any part of the vaccine, which this patient does not have.

The Hib vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations and would have already completed four routine doses of the Hib vaccine. Additional doses of the Hib vaccine are only recommended for high-risk individuals (e.g., individuals with asplenia or a history of hematopoietic stem cell transplant). This patient does not have any of these risk factors.

F) INCORRECT:

The meningococcal ACWY vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations, so he has already completed two routine doses of the meningococcal ACWY vaccine. Additional doses of the meningococcal vaccine are only recommended for high-risk individuals (e.g., military recruits, first-year college students who reside in residential dormitory housing if not already vaccinated at ≥ 16 years of age; individuals with asplenia, HIV infection, complement inhibitor use, or a history of travel to high-risk countries). This patient does not have any of these risk factors.

The Hib vaccine is not recommended because this individual is up-to-date with his childhood vaccinations and would have already completed four routine doses of the Hib vaccine. Additional doses of the Hib vaccine are only recommended for high-risk individuals (e.g., individuals with asplenia or a history of hematopoietic stem cell transplant). This patient does not have any of these risk factors.
questions.hint: This patient was appropriately vaccinated with the meningococcal vaccine prior to living in residential dormitory housing.

questions.text: A 1-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for a scheduled immunization visit. The patient's father reports that the patient had continual crying, increased irritability, and fever for the past 2 days. He has noticed that the patient keeps tugging at his left ear. The patient was born at 32 weeks' gestation but has been otherwise healthy and has no history of serious illness. At the fourth well-child visit, the third dose of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis, Hemophilus influenza type b (Hib), pneumococcal conjugate (PCV15), inactivated poliovirus, and hepatitis B (HepB) vaccines were administered. He is at the 25th percentile for length and weight with respect to chronological age; when corrected for gestational age, he is at the 40th percentile for length and weight. His temperature is 37.8ºC (100.1ºF); the remainder of his vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination of the left ear shows an erythematous, bulging tympanic membrane; examination of the right ear shows no abnormalities. Treatment with ibuprofen and amoxicillin is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation by the physician regarding immunization?

choices.text: Administer standard doses of all vaccines due at this visit
Administer weight-adjusted doses of all due vaccines after the illness resolves
Administer standard doses of all due vaccines after 5 weeks
Administer weight-adjusted doses of all vaccines due at this visit
Administer standard doses of inactivated vaccines at this visit and live vaccines after the illness resolves

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient should receive the standard doses of all vaccines due at this visit. Neither mild acute illness (e.g., upper respiratory tract infection, otitis media, low-grade fever, mild diarrhea) nor current antibiotic therapy are contraindications for vaccination (except for oral live typhoid vaccine, because antibiotics might compromise the immune response to this vaccine). All children must be immunized with the standard doses of vaccines according to their chronological age; doses should not be adjusted to weight or gestational age.

The only vaccine that depends on the child's birth weight is the first dose of HepB vaccine; infants with a birth weight < 2 kg should receive the first dose of the vaccine at 1 month of age or at hospital discharge, whichever occurs first.

B) INCORRECT:

Valid contraindications for vaccination include previous severe allergic reactions related to vaccination (e.g., anaphylaxis) and severe allergies to components of a vaccine. Moderate to severe acute illness with or without fever is a precaution for vaccine administration. Mild illnesses, such as otitis media and low-grade fever are not contraindications for vaccination. Adjusting the dosage based on weight is not recommended for the vaccines indicated in this patient (Hib vaccine, PCV15, varicella vaccine, and measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine).

C) INCORRECT:

Preterm infants should be vaccinated at the same chronological age, according to the same schedule, and using the same precautions as full-term infants. Correction for gestational age is not recommended.

D) INCORRECT:

Vaccination is contraindicated in patients who have experienced a severe allergic reaction to a prior dose or component of a vaccine, which is not seen here. However, adjusting the dosage based on weight is not recommended for the vaccines indicated in this patient (Hib vaccine, PCV15, varicella vaccine, and measles, mumps, and rubella vaccine).

E) INCORRECT:

Live attenuated vaccines are not recommended in pregnant and/or immunocompromised individuals (e.g., those receiving immunosuppressive therapy, patients with congenital immunodeficiencies, severely immunocompromised patients with HIV). In such cases, the standard doses of inactivated vaccines might be indicated, but the administration of live vaccines should be postponed until after delivery or until the patient is no longer considered immunocompromised. This patient has neither of these contraindications, so another approach would be more appropriate.
questions.hint: If there are no absolute contraindications, immunizations indicated at 12 months include the fourth Hib dose; fourth PCV15 dose; first measles, mumps, and rubella dose; and first varicella dose.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and a 14-year history of mild-to-moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, as defined by the Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease stages, presents in the late fall for routine follow-up. His current medications are inhaled albuterol as needed and metformin. He has a 30-pack-year history of cigarette smoking but quit 13 years ago.
He received an influenza immunization one year ago and is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations. He has also received the 15-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine followed by the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine.
Which one of the following immunization plans for influenza and pneumococcal disease is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine and 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine
Inactivated influenza vaccine and 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine
Intranasal live influenza vaccine and 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If a person receives PCV15, it should be followed by a dose of 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23). The 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13) is no longer recommended. This patient is up to date on his pneumococcal vaccination and should receive only the influenza vaccine at this visit.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient is up to date on his pneumococcal vaccination and should receive only the influenza vaccine at this visit.

C) CORRECT:

This patient is up to date on his pneumococcal vaccination and should receive only the inactivated influenza vaccine at this visit.

Influenza Vaccination

Annual influenza immunization is recommended for all individuals over 6 months of age. Multiple formulations of the influenza vaccine are available:

• High-dose or adjuvant-based inactivated influenza vaccine injections that are licensed only for individuals aged 65 or older.
• Standard-dose inactivated influenza vaccine injections are used in children and adults up to 64 years of age.
• The nasal spray influenza vaccine containing live attenuated virus can be used in individuals 2 to 49 years of age who are not pregnant and who do not have immunosuppression or other high-risk medical conditions.

Pneumococcal Vaccination

Pneumococcal vaccination is recommended for all adults aged ≥ 50 years and for those aged 19 to 49 years who have particular underlying conditions or risk factors, including alcohol use disorder; chronic heart, liver, or lung disease; chronic renal failure; cigarette smoking; cochlear implant; congenital or acquired asplenia; cerebrospinal fluid leak; diabetes mellitus; generalized malignancy; HIV; Hodgkin disease; immunodeficiency; iatrogenic immunosuppression; leukemia; lymphoma; multiple myeloma; nephrotic syndrome; solid organ transplants; or sickle cell disease or other hemoglobinopathies.

Adult patients who are eligible for pneumococcal vaccination should receive one dose of 15-, 20-, or 21-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV15, PCV20, or PCV21). If a person receives PCV15, it should be followed by a dose of 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23), usually at least one year later; PPSV23 is not needed if the patient receives PCV20 or PCV21.

Previous pneumococcal vaccination guidelines recommended the 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13). This particular vaccine is no longer recommended, but the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention provides guidance for clinicians on pneumococcal immunizations in patients who have been vaccinated following older guidelines or who have received partial vaccination.

Key learning point: Patients of any age with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease should receive pneumococcal vaccination and an annual influenza vaccine.

D) INCORRECT:

The nasal spray influenza vaccine containing live attenuated virus can be used in individuals 2 to 49 years of age who are not pregnant and who do not have immunosuppression or other high-risk medical conditions. Individuals aged ≥ 50 years should receive the inactivated influenza vaccine.

E) INCORRECT:

The nasal spray influenza vaccine containing live attenuated virus can be used in individuals 2 to 49 years of age who are not pregnant and who do not have immunosuppression or other high-risk medical conditions. Individuals aged ≥ 50 years should receive the inactivated influenza vaccine. Moreover, this patient is up to date on his pneumococcal vaccination.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents for a routine physical examination in June. He is planning a month-long visit to Taiwan in 4 weeks and asks about pretravel vaccinations. He was born in Taiwan but moved to the United States in infancy and received all recommended vaccinations until graduating high school. Since then, he has received a yearly influenza vaccination, and he is up to date with his Covid-19 vaccinations. He also received a dose of tetanus and diphtheria toxoids (Td) booster 5 years ago.
He has a history of allergic rhinitis and hypertension for which he takes fluticasone and lisinopril. He lives alone and works as a first-grade teacher. He smokes one-half pack of cigarettes daily and drinks alcohol only occasionally.
Which one of the following vaccinations is indicated for this patient at this visit?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The childhood vaccination schedule recommends two doses of the measles-mumps-rubella (MMR) vaccine. In individuals who already received two doses, there is no recommendation for a booster dose of the MMR vaccine in adulthood except in persons identified by public health authorities as potentially at increased risk for acquiring mumps because of an outbreak; those individuals should receive a third dose of a mumps virus-containing vaccine.

B) CORRECT:

Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus) is a gram-positive diplococcus responsible for serious infections in adults, including pneumonia, bacteremia, and meningitis. Pneumococcal vaccination is recommended for all adults aged ≥ 65 years and for those aged 19 to 64 years who have particular underlying conditions or risk factors, including alcohol use disorder; chronic heart, liver, or lung disease; chronic renal failure; cigarette smoking; cochlear implant; congenital or acquired asplenia; cerebrospinal fluid leak; diabetes mellitus; generalized malignancy; HIV; Hodgkin disease; immunodeficiency; iatrogenic immunosuppression; leukemia; lymphoma; multiple myeloma; nephrotic syndrome; solid organ transplants; or sickle cell disease or other hemoglobinopathies.

Given this patient’s history of tobacco use, he should be offered pneumococcal vaccination with one dose of 15- or 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV15 or PCV20). If he receives PCV15, it should be followed by a dose of 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23), usually at least one year later; PPSV23 is not needed if the patient receives PCV20.

Key learning point: Current tobacco use is an indication for vaccination against pneumococcus.

C) INCORRECT:

Neither yellow fever nor typhoid vaccination is routinely recommended for travel to Taiwan.

D) INCORRECT:

Neither yellow fever nor typhoid vaccination is routinely recommended for travel to Taiwan.

E) INCORRECT:

Influenza vaccine is the first and most important step in protecting against influenza. However, a vaccine formulated for one year may be ineffective for the following year because the influenza virus evolves rapidly with new strains that quickly replace older ones. For this reason, influenza vaccination occurs in the fall in the United States. For travel to Taiwan, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that patients be up to date on their influenza vaccination. In this case, the patient received the influenza vaccine during the previous fall, so it should not be repeated in June, which is before the influenza vaccine is updated in the U.S.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman asks whether she is eligible to receive vaccination against herpes zoster (shingles). Her medical history is significant for one episode of herpes zoster 10 years ago on her right flank, rheumatoid arthritis that is well controlled with prednisone 10 mg daily, and insulin-requiring type 2 diabetes with fasting blood glucose levels ranging from 180 mg/dL to 250 mg/dL (reference range for diabetes, >125 mg/dL). Her last glycated hemoglobin level was 9%.
What is the most appropriate answer to this patient’s question?

choices.text: She is ineligible to receive the recombinant zoster vaccine because of her prednisone use
She is ineligible to receive the recombinant zoster vaccine because of her prior episode of shingles
She can receive the recombinant zoster vaccine after her diabetes is better controlled
She is eligible to receive the recombinant zoster vaccine
She is ineligible to receive the recombinant zoster vaccine because she is older than age 60

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) is recommended for individuals aged ≥19 years who are or will be immunocompromised. It can be administered safely to adults with chronic medical conditions or who are on immunosuppressive therapy, such as prednisone.

B) INCORRECT:

RZV can be administered safely to adults with a prior history of herpes zoster, although the vaccine should not be administered until after any active episode has resolved.

C) INCORRECT:

RZV can be administered safely to adults with chronic medical conditions, including diabetes mellitus, regardless of the level of control of the condition.

D) CORRECT:

Herpes zoster vaccination reduces the incidence of herpes zoster (shingles) and the incidence and severity of postherpetic neuralgia. The recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) is recommended for all individuals aged ≥50 years (with no upper age limit) and for individuals ≥19 years who are or will be immunocompromised. It should be administered in two doses spaced 2 to 6 months apart.

RZV can be administered safely to adults with a prior history of herpes zoster (although the vaccine should not be administered until after any active episode has resolved) and to adults with chronic medical conditions, including diabetes mellitus and rheumatoid arthritis.

The zoster vaccine live (ZVL), which was contraindicated in patients with significant immunosuppression, is no longer available. Individuals who previously received this vaccine can safely receive two doses of RZV as long as the first dose is administered at least 2 months after receipt of ZVL.

Key learning point: Herpes zoster vaccination with the recombinant zoster vaccine is recommended for all people aged ≥50 years, regardless of whether they have a previous history of herpes zoster, and also for individuals aged ≥19 years who are or will be immunodeficient or immunosuppressed.

E) INCORRECT:

The recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) is recommended for all individuals aged ≥50 years (with no upper age limit), so age greater than 60 does not make someone ineligible for the vaccine.

questions.text:
A 71-year-old woman with hypertension, systemic lupus erythematosus, and end-stage kidney disease secondary to lupus nephritis is seen for her annual examination. Her lupus is currently quiescent; she takes only hydroxychloroquine. She has required hemodialysis for 8 years. Recently, she started the evaluation process for kidney transplantation.
She received the 23-valent and 13-valent pneumococcal vaccines within the past 2 years. She received this season's influenza vaccine in the dialysis unit 3 months ago and received a tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis vaccine last year. She is up to date with Covid-19 and respiratory syncytial virus vaccinations. Previous testing for hepatitis A immunoglobulin G antibody (anti-HAV IgG) and antibody to hepatitis B surface antigen (anti-HBs) was positive.
Which one of the following additional vaccines is indicated for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The hepatitis A vaccine is recommended for patients receiving hemodialysis who are seeking protection from hepatitis A virus infection and also for patients who have other indications, such as men who have sex with men, people who use illicit drugs, people with chronic liver disease or HIV, and those traveling to an endemic area. This patient has immunity to hepatitis A virus, and booster vaccination is not indicated. The patient is also immune to hepatitis B virus and thus has no indication for hepatitis B vaccine.

B) INCORRECT:

The meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine is indicated for military recruits, college students, people with HIV, those with asplenia or persistent complement deficiencies, those with relevant occupational exposures (e.g., microbiologists), and those who travel to or live in countries in which meningococcal disease is hyperendemic or epidemic. This vaccine is not indicated for patients who have undergone, or are about to undergo, organ transplantation.

C) INCORRECT:
