The measles-mumps-rubella booster is not recommended in preparation for immunosuppression. Also, because this patient was born before 1957, she is considered immune to measles and mumps.

D) CORRECT:

Herpes zoster vaccination reduces the incidence of herpes zoster (shingles) and the incidence and severity of postherpetic neuralgia. The recombinant zoster vaccine is recommended for all individuals aged ≥50 years and for those aged ≥19 years who are or will be immunocompromised. It should be administered in two doses spaced 2 to 6 months apart and is considered safe in patients with a previous episode of herpes zoster or a chronic medical condition.

The zoster vaccine live, which was contraindicated in severely immunocompromised patients, is no longer available.

Key learning point: The recombinant zoster vaccine is recommended for all individuals aged ≥50 years and for those aged ≥19 years who are or will be immunocompromised.

E) INCORRECT:

The Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccine is indicated in adults with anatomical or functional asplenia, in those who have complement deficiencies, and in recipients of hematopoietic stem-cell transplants.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old man is transferred to a rehabilitation facility after being hospitalized for a hip fracture. During his hospitalization, he was diagnosed with multiple myeloma and started chemotherapy. He has no other significant medical issues and recently had a negative tuberculin skin test.
His vaccination history includes receipt of the influenza vaccine and Covid-19 vaccines shortly before he started chemotherapy and receipt of the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (but not a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine) 2 years ago.
Which one of the following vaccinations is recommended for this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices recommends the 15-valent or 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV15 or PCV20) for all adults aged ≥65 years and for adults aged 19 to 64 years with particular underlying conditions — for example, immunocompromising conditions (including HIV infection and malignancies), functional or anatomic asplenia, cerebrospinal fluid leaks, or cochlear implants. Adults who have previously received only the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) should receive either PCV15 or PCV20 at least one year after their last PPSV23 dose.

Patients with multiple myeloma are at particularly high risk for invasive disease due to encapsulated organisms, especially Streptococcus pneumoniae. This patient received PPSV23 two years ago and should now receive PCV15 or PCV20.

Key learning point: When pneumococcal vaccination is indicated and the patient has received only a dose of the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine, a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (15-valent or 20-valent) should also be given.

B) INCORRECT:

The measles-mumps-rubella booster is a live attenuated vaccine that is contraindicated in many immunocompromised patients such as this one. Also, because this patient was born before 1957, he is considered immune to measles and mumps.

C) INCORRECT:

Adults who have previously received only the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) should receive either PCV15 or PCV20 at least one year after their last PPSV23 dose. This patient received PPSV23 two years ago and should now receive PCV15 or PCV20.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient should receive zoster vaccination but not with the zoster vaccine live, which is contraindicated in immunocompromised patients and is no longer available in the United States. Instead, the recombinant zoster vaccine is recommended. It is indicated for all adults aged ≥ 50 years and for those ≥ 19 years who are or will be immunocompromised by disease or treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

The meningococcal vaccine is not appropriate for this patient because it is indicated only for people with asplenia and complement deficiencies, for high-risk groups (including military recruits, college students, and people with HIV), and for people in regions with epidemic meningococcal disease.

questions.text:
A one-day-old female infant is evaluated in the hospital. She was born at 35 weeks’ gestation to a primigravida woman and had a birth weight of 1900 grams. The mother tested negative for hepatitis B virus surface antigen immediately before delivery. The infant is healthy and will go home with the mother.
Which one of the following hepatitis B vaccine recommendations is most appropriate for this infant?

choices.text: Give the hepatitis B vaccine at hospital discharge
Give the hepatitis B vaccine at 3 months of age if the infant’s weight exceeds 4000 grams
Give the hepatitis B vaccine when the infant’s weight exceeds 3000 grams
Give the combined hepatitis B- Haemophilus influenzae type b conjugate vaccine at one month of age
Give the hepatitis B vaccine at 3 months of age if the infant's weight exceeds 3000 grams

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Guidelines for hepatitis B virus (HBV) vaccination were updated in early 2018 to recommend that most infants receive the first dose of vaccine within 24 hours of birth, instead of prior to discharge as previously recommended. However, this new recommendation does not apply to preterm infants who are born to hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg)-negative mothers and weigh less than 2000 grams (as in this case). Because of the concern that underweight premature infants may not be able to mount a sufficient immune response to vaccination, these infants should receive their first dose of HBV vaccine either at one month of age or at the time of hospital discharge, whichever comes first. Administering the initial vaccine dose as early as possible for all infants helps ensure that patients complete the three-dose series in as timely a manner as possible.

If the mother tests positive for hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg), the HBV vaccine should ideally be given within the first 12 hours of life, regardless of birth weight or gestational age, and should be followed by hepatitis B immune globulin (HBIG). This first HBV vaccine, given at birth, does not count in the series, and the infant should then receive three additional vaccines starting at 1 to 2 months of age, for a total of four HBV vaccines.

If the mother’s HBsAg status is unknown, the HBV vaccine should be given within 12 hours of birth, the mother should be tested for HBsAg immediately; if the HBsAg result comes back positive or is unavailable, HBIG should be administered. For infants weighing <2000 grams, HBIG should also be given within the first 12 hours if the mother is confirmed to be HBV positive or if her status cannot be confirmed by that time.

Key learning point: In a healthy infant whose birth weight is less than 2000 grams and whose mother tests negative for hepatitis B surface antigen, the first dose of hepatitis B vaccine should be given at one month of age or at hospital discharge, whichever comes first.

B) INCORRECT:

There is no need to wait until the infant weighs 4000 grams to administer HBV vaccine.

C) INCORRECT:

There is no need to wait until the infant weighs 3000 grams to administer HBV vaccine.

D) INCORRECT:

Only the single-antigen vaccine should be given to infants under 2 months of age. The immunogenicity of the combined HBV-Hib (Haemophilus influenzae type b) conjugate vaccine and the combined HBV-DTaP-IPV (diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis and inactivated poliovirus) vaccine is equivalent to that of their individual antigens administered separately. However, these vaccines cannot be administered to infants younger than 2 months of age.

E) INCORRECT:

There is no need to wait until the infant weighs 3000 to administer HBV vaccine.

questions.text:
A 14-year-old girl with mild persistent asthma presents for follow-up one week after being hospitalized for status asthmaticus and influenza B virus infection. She has received all age-appropriate vaccines except for this year’s influenza immunization and is hesitant to receive the vaccine at this visit.
What vaccination strategy is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Counsel the patient about the importance of receiving this year’s influenza vaccine, and recommend intranasal delivery
Defer influenza vaccination, and start chemoprophylaxis with oseltamivir for the remainder of influenza season
Defer influenza vaccination this year, but reinforce the importance of the annual vaccine for next year
Defer administering influenza immunization now but plan to administer it in one month
Counsel the patient about the importance of receiving this year’s influenza vaccine, and recommend delivery of inactivated influenza vaccine by injection

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Annual seasonal influenza vaccination is recommended for all individuals aged 6 months and older. Given this patient’s history of asthma, she should receive the intramuscular inactivated influenza vaccine rather than the intranasal live attenuated influenza vaccine. The intranasal form of the vaccine is an alternative to the inactivated intramuscular influenza vaccine for immunocompetent children and adults aged 2 to 49 years without a history of asthma — and in younger children, ages 2 to 4 years, without a history of wheezing in the past 12 months.

B) INCORRECT:

Chemoprophylaxis may be indicated for certain patients who cannot receive the influenza vaccine but should not be used as a substitute for immunization.

C) INCORRECT:

Deferring administration of the influenza vaccine is not appropriate, because it would leave the patient unprotected during this time. Annual seasonal influenza vaccination is recommended for all individuals aged 6 months and older. Vaccination is recommended even for patients who have already contracted influenza that year.

D) INCORRECT:

Deferring administration of the influenza vaccine is not appropriate, because it would leave the patient unprotected during this time.

E) CORRECT:

Because influenza virus undergoes antigenic shift and antigenic drift, the influenza vaccine is modified annually. Surveillance data collected by the World Health Organization and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention are used to predict which strains of influenza will be most prevalent for a coming year. All current influenza vaccines are quadrivalent, containing two strains each of influenza A (including H1N1) and influenza B.

Annual seasonal influenza vaccination is recommended for all individuals aged 6 months and older. Vaccination is recommended even for patients who have already contracted influenza that year.

Given this patient’s history of asthma, she should receive the intramuscular inactivated influenza vaccine rather than the intranasal live attenuated influenza vaccine. The intranasal form of the vaccine is an alternative to the inactivated intramuscular influenza vaccine for immunocompetent children and adults aged 2 to 49 years without a history of asthma — and in younger children, ages 2 to 4 years, without a history of wheezing in the past 12 months.

Chemoprophylaxis may be indicated for certain patients who cannot receive the influenza vaccine but should not be used as a substitute for immunization.

Key learning point: The composition of the influenza vaccine changes annually because the most prevalent circulating strains of influenza virus change annually.

questions.text:
A 9-month-old girl returns to clinic after a 5-month lapse in visits. At her 2- and 4-month visits, she received one dose each of the following vaccines:

Combination diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP), inactivated poliovirus (IPV), and Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
Hepatitis B virus (HBV)
13-valent pneumococcal conjugate (PCV13)
Rotavirus

The patient is growing and developing appropriately. She has had rhinorrhea and cough for 3 days but has otherwise been well.
On examination, she is afebrile and appears well.
What is the most appropriate approach to managing this patient's vaccinations?

choices.text: Plan to continue the child's vaccination series with DTaP, Hib, and IPV when her respiratory symptoms have resolved
Restart the child's vaccination series with DTaP, Hib, PCV (either PCV15 or PCV20), and IPV one week after her coryza resolves
Continue the child's vaccination series today with HBV, DTaP, Hib, PCV (either PCV15 or PCV20), IPV, and rotavirus
Continue the child's vaccination series today with HBV, DTaP, Hib, PCV (either PCV15 or PCV20), and IPV
Restart the child's vaccination series today with HBV, DTaP, Hib, PCV (either PCV15 or PCV20), IPV, and rotavirus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vaccinations should not be delayed for a mild respiratory tract illness, with or without fever. Vaccinating children with mild illnesses is safe and efficacious, and it is important that this child's immunizations not be further delayed.

B) INCORRECT:

Restarting the series of delayed vaccinations is not necessary. Available studies of extended intervals between multidose vaccine series demonstrate no significant difference in final titers.

Vaccinations should not be delayed for a mild respiratory tract illness, with or without fever. Vaccinating children with mild illnesses is safe and efficacious, and it is important that this child's immunizations not be further delayed.

C) INCORRECT:

The maximum age for the first dose of the rotavirus vaccine is 14 weeks and 6 days; the maximum age for the final dose in the series is 8 months and 0 days. Infants older than 8 months of age should not receive the rotavirus vaccine, even if their series is incomplete, because the vaccine’s safety has not been proven for children over 8 months of age.

D) CORRECT:

With the exception of rotavirus vaccination, this child should receive all of the vaccines she would have received at her 6-month visit: hepatitis B virus (HBV), diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP), Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (either PCV15 or PCV20, as they are interchangeable), and inactivated poliovirus (IPV).

The maximum age for the first dose of the rotavirus vaccine is 14 weeks and 6 days; the maximum age for the final dose in the series is 8 months and 0 days. Infants older than 8 months of age should not receive the rotavirus vaccine, even if their series is incomplete, because the vaccine’s safety has not been proven for children over 8 months of age.

Key learning point: The vaccination plan for a 9-month-old child who has not received any vaccines since she was 4 months old should be resumed as soon as possible without need to restart the series.

E) INCORRECT:

Restarting the series of delayed vaccinations is not necessary. Available studies of extended intervals between multidose vaccine series demonstrate no significant difference in final titers.

The maximum age for the first dose of the rotavirus vaccine is 14 weeks and 6 days; the maximum age for the final dose in the series is 8 months and 0 days. Infants older than 8 months of age should not receive the rotavirus vaccine, even if their series is incomplete, because the vaccine’s safety has not been proven for children over 8 months of age.

questions.text:
A 12-month-old girl with sickle cell disease is being seen for well-child care. She is growing and developing normally. She takes penicillin prophylaxis and has not had any complications of her sickle cell disease. She has received three doses of the 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine — at 2 months, 4 months, and 9 months of age.
Which one of the following strategies is most appropriate for managing this patient's pneumococcal vaccination?

choices.text: Administer the 15-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine at this visit
Do not administer any further pneumococcal vaccine; immunization is up to date
Administer the 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine at this visit
Administer the 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine and the 23-valent polysaccharide vaccine at this visit
Advise the patient's mother to return in 5 months so that the patient can receive the 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommend that all children receive vaccinations against pneumococcal disease. The 13-valent, 15-valent, and 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccines (PCV13, PCV15, and PCV20) contain 13, 15, and 20 serotypes of Streptococcus pneumoniae, respectively.

With the development of the 15-valent and 20-valent vaccines, the 13-valent vaccine has been phased out and is no longer available. Either PCV15 or PCV20 should be given at 2 months, 4 months, and 6 months of age (with at least 4 weeks between doses), and a fourth, booster dose is recommended at 12 to 15 months of age, at least 8 weeks after the third dose. This patient is 12 months old and received PCV13 for her primary series, with the third dose given 3 months ago, so she should receive a booster dose of PCV15 or PCV20 now. Interruption of the vaccination schedule does not require reinstitution of the entire series or the addition of extra doses.

A child with sickle cell disease who has not received PCV20 as part of their standard PCV series before the age of 2 years should receive two doses of PCV20 or PPSV23 (23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine) — the first at age ≥ 2 years and the second 5 years later. This recommendation also applies to children with other hemoglobinopathies, primary or acquired immunodeficiencies, and those on long-term dialysis. For children with chronic heart or lung disease, diabetes mellitus, cerebrospinal fluid leaks, or cochlear implants, a single dose of PCV20 or PPSV23 at ≥ 2 years is recommended if they did not receive PCV20 in their standard PCV series.

Key learning point: The 15-valent or 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine should be administered at ages 2 months, 4 months, and 6 months, with a booster dose at 12 to 15 months (at least 8 weeks after the third dose).

B) INCORRECT:

This patient's immunization is not up to date; she requires further pneumococcal vaccination.

C) INCORRECT:

The minimum age for the first dose of PPSV23 is 2 years.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient can receive PCV20 now but a conjugate vaccine (PCV) and a polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) cannot be given at the same visit. Moreover, the minimum age for the first dose of PPSV23 is 2 years.

E) INCORRECT:

A fourth booster dose of pneumococcal vaccination is recommended at 12 to 15 months of age, at least 8 weeks after the third dose. This patient is 12 months old and received the third dose 3 months ago, so she should receive a booster dose now.

questions.text:
A healthy 9-month-old boy presents for a routine well-child visit. He did not receive his diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine or his inactivated poliovirus vaccine at his 6-month visit, but he did receive pneumococcal conjugate, hepatitis B, and Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccines at that visit. His vital signs are within normal limits, and he appears well.
Which vaccines should the patient receive at this visit?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient should receive both of the vaccines that he missed at 6 months: DTaP and poliovirus. These vaccines can be given simultaneously at the same visit.

B) INCORRECT:

All children should receive vaccines to prevent diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis. Children younger than 7 years of age should receive five doses of the diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine.

C) INCORRECT:

Adolescents should receive the tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine one time between the ages of 11 and 12. Children younger than 7 years of age should receive five doses of the diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine on the following schedule: 2 months of age, 4 months of age, 6 months of age, 15 to 18 months of age, and 4 to 6 years of age.

D) INCORRECT:

Adolescents should receive the tetanus-diphtheria-acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine one time between the ages of 11 and 12. Children younger than 7 years of age should receive five doses of the diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine on the following schedule: 2 months of age, 4 months of age, 6 months of age, 15 to 18 months of age, and 4 to 6 years of age.

E) CORRECT:

All children should receive vaccines to prevent diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis. Diphtheria causes a thick membranous covering in the back of the throat, leading to breathing problems. Tetanus is a toxin-producing bacterial infection that can cause painful tightening of the muscles. Pertussis causes whooping cough and is associated with high risk for morbidity and mortality when infection occurs in the first year of life. Diphtheria and pertussis are spread via person-to-person contact, and tetanus is acquired through cuts and wounds.

Several formulations of the diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine are available, and the appropriate choice depends on the patient's age.

Children younger than 7 years of age should receive five doses of the diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine on the following schedule: 2 months of age, 4 months of age, 6 months of age, 15 to 18 months of age, and 4 to 6 years of age.

This patient should receive both of the vaccines that he missed at 6 months: DTaP and poliovirus. These vaccines can be given simultaneously at the same visit. If influenza season is approaching and the vaccine is available, inactivated influenza vaccine should also be administered.

The next pneumococcal conjugate vaccine should be administered at 12 to 15 months.

Key learning point: For children under 7 years of age, the appropriate vaccine formulation to prevent diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis is DTaP.

questions.text:
A healthy 6-month-old girl is brought in for a well-child visit and receives the following vaccines:

Diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis

Haemophilus influenzae type b
Inactivated poliovirus
Rotavirus
Pneumococcal conjugate
Inactivated influenza vaccine

She has received all prior recommended vaccinations.
At what age should this patient receive her next dose of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) should be administered as a routine vaccination at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.

B) INCORRECT:

The diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) should be administered as a routine vaccination at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.

C) INCORRECT:

The diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) should be administered as a routine vaccination at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.

D) INCORRECT:

The diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) should be administered as a routine vaccination at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.

E) CORRECT:

All children should receive vaccines to prevent diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis. Diphtheria is spread via person-to-person contact and causes a thick, membranous covering in the back of the throat that can lead to breathing problems. Pertussis is also spread via person-to-person contact and causes whooping cough; infection in the first year of life, particularly in unimmunized children, is associated with high risk of morbidity and mortality. Tetanus, which is acquired through cuts and wounds, causes painful tightening of the muscles.

The diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) should be administered as a routine vaccination at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years. This patient, who is 6 months old, should receive her next dose of DTaP at 15 to 18 months of age. Children can receive the fourth dose of DTaP vaccine as early as 12 months of age, as long as 6 months have elapsed since receipt of the third dose.

The vaccine can be given during mild illness, such as a cold, but may be postponed for moderate-to-severe illness.

The vaccine should not be given to patients who have had a life-threatening allergic reaction to a previous dose or to any of the vaccine components. It also should not be given to patients who have had encephalopathy not attributable to another identifiable cause (e.g., coma, decreased level of consciousness, prolonged seizures within 7 days of being given a previous dose of DTaP or another pertussis-containing vaccine).

Key learning point: Diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine should be given at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.

questions.text:
A 2-month-old boy is brought in by his mother for a well-child visit. The mother is concerned about the number of vaccines he is supposed to receive at this visit and is specifically concerned about the Haemophilus influenzae type b vaccine.
Which one of the following schedules for the Haemophilus influenzae type b conjugate vaccine is recommended?

choices.text: A two- or three-dose primary series beginning at 2 months of age, with a single booster dose between 12 and 15 months of age
A two- or three-dose primary series beginning at 6 months of age, with booster doses at 12 and 15 months of age
A two- or three-dose primary series beginning at 6 months of age, with a single booster dose between 12 and 15 months of age
A two- or three-dose primary series beginning at 2 months of age, with booster doses at 12 and 15 months of age
A four-dose primary series beginning at 4 months of age, with no subsequent booster dose

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Before the vaccine for Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) was available, this pathogen was the leading cause of bacterial meningitis and invasive bacterial disease in children younger than 5 years of age. The age peak for invasive disease is between 6 and 18 months. Hib is also responsible for causing other serious infections, including pneumonia, epiglottitis, cellulitis, osteomyelitis, septic arthritis, and purulent pericarditis. Immunization has reduced the incidence of Hib disease by over 99% and the few cases that occur in the United States each year primarily occur in unvaccinated children.

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that the Hib conjugate vaccine be administered to all children according to the following schedule: a two- or three-dose primary series (depending on the formulation) beginning at 2 months of age, with each dose separated by 2 months, and then a single booster given between 12 and 15 months of age. The vaccine is not approved for healthy patients older than 5 years of age but is indicated for unimmunized children with underlying conditions such as sickle cell anemia or HIV infection that may predispose them to invasive Hib disease.

Key learning point: The recommended schedule for the Haemophilus influenzae type b conjugate vaccine is a two- or three-dose primary series beginning at 2 months of age, with a single booster dose between 12 and 15 months of age.

B) INCORRECT:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that the Hib conjugate vaccine be administered to all children according to the following schedule: a two- or three-dose primary series (depending on the formulation) beginning at 2 months of age, with each dose separated by 2 months, and then a single booster given between 12 and 15 months of age.

C) INCORRECT:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that the Hib conjugate vaccine be administered to all children according to the following schedule: a two- or three-dose primary series (depending on the formulation) beginning at 2 months of age, with each dose separated by 2 months, and then a single booster given between 12 and 15 months of age.

D) INCORRECT:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that the Hib conjugate vaccine be administered to all children according to the following schedule: a two- or three-dose primary series (depending on the formulation) beginning at 2 months of age, with each dose separated by 2 months, and then a single booster given between 12 and 15 months of age.

E) INCORRECT:

The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention recommends that the Hib conjugate vaccine be administered to all children according to the following schedule: a two- or three-dose primary series (depending on the formulation) beginning at 2 months of age, with each dose separated by 2 months, and then a single booster given between 12 and 15 months of age.

questions.text:
A 12-month-old girl is brought in for a well-child check. She was born at 28 weeks’ gestation by cesarean section because of severe maternal preeclampsia. She was hospitalized for 8 weeks in the neonatal intensive care unit and was discharged home with no serious sequelae of her prematurity.
On examination, the infant appears well, and the mother has no concerns.
What vaccinations should this child receive?

choices.text: Full immunization in accordance with her chronologic age, with the exception of influenza vaccine
Full immunization in accordance with her corrected gestational age, with the exception of live attenuated vaccines
Full immunization in accordance with her chronologic age, including live attenuated vaccines
Full immunization in accordance with her chronologic age, with the exception of live attenuated vaccines
Full immunization in accordance with her corrected gestational age, including live attenuated vaccines

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

All infants, including preterm and low-birth weight infants, should receive inactivated influenza vaccine beginning at a chronologic age of 6 months. Children younger than 8 years of age who are receiving the influenza vaccine for the first time require two doses of vaccine administered at least 4 weeks apart.

B) INCORRECT:

Preterm and low-birth-weight infants are at increased risk for morbidity and mortality from vaccine-preventable illnesses. Accordingly, medically stable preterm and low-birth-weight infants are advised to receive the same set of immunizations as full-term infants in accordance with their chronologic age. This recommendation includes immunization with live attenuated vaccines (measles-mumps-rubella and varicella-zoster virus), which have been demonstrated to pose no increased risk to the stable preterm or low-birth-weight infant.

C) CORRECT:

In a preterm infant, “corrected gestational age” refers to the age that the child would be if he or she had been born at term; chronologic age refers to the child’s age relative to his or her actual date of birth.

Preterm and low-birth-weight infants are at increased risk for morbidity and mortality from vaccine-preventable illnesses. Accordingly, medically stable preterm and low-birth-weight infants are advised to receive the same set of immunizations as full-term infants in accordance with their chronologic age. This recommendation includes immunization with live attenuated vaccines (measles-mumps-rubella and varicella-zoster virus), which have been demonstrated to pose no increased risk to the stable preterm or low-birth-weight infant.

Key learning point: The recommended vaccine schedule for medically stable preterm infants is full immunization in accordance with their chronologic age, including live attenuated vaccines.

D) INCORRECT:

Preterm and low-birth-weight infants are at increased risk for morbidity and mortality from vaccine-preventable illnesses. Accordingly, medically stable preterm and low-birth-weight infants are advised to receive the same set of immunizations as full-term infants in accordance with their chronologic age. This recommendation includes immunization with live attenuated vaccines (measles-mumps-rubella and varicella-zoster virus), which have been demonstrated to pose no increased risk to the stable preterm or low-birth-weight infant.

E) INCORRECT:

Preterm and low-birth-weight infants are at increased risk for morbidity and mortality from vaccine-preventable illnesses. Accordingly, medically stable preterm and low-birth-weight infants are advised to receive the same set of immunizations as full-term infants in accordance with their chronologic age.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to the office because of a 2-week history of genital lesions. She has no history of serious illness. She is sexually active with 2 male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules over the vulva. The lesions turn white on application of 3% acetic acid. Which of the following is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although condom use may help reduce the risk of HPV transmission, studies have shown that contact with uncovered areas still allows for HPV transmission. Condom use is therefore not the best option for preventing this patient's condition.

B) INCORRECT:

HIV can present with genital lesions in a sexually active individual. Molluscum contagiosum, which is a common genital lesion in adults associated with HIV, could present with a nontender, exophytic papule on the genitalia. However, these lesions would have a characteristic hemispherical, umbilicated appearance, and they would not turn white on application of 3% acetic acid. Moreover, there are no other features in this patient that suggest immunocompromise, which is typical of HIV.

C) INCORRECT:

Spermicidal foams and gels are means of contraception with medium efficacy and may be used by sexually active individuals who do not intend to get pregnant. However, they do not provide any protection against sexually transmitted infections, such as the one in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

Famciclovir is used for the treatment and prophylaxis of genital herpes caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV-1 or HSV-2). A case of genital herpes could present with multiple raised lesions over the vulva. However, the lesions would be vesicular or ulcerative, very painful, and associated with systemic features (like fever, lymphadenopathy, etc.), which are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Photograph of the anogenital region of an adult female patient

Fluid-filled vesicles on erythematous bases are visible around the anus and vulva. Some of these vesicles have ruptured, leaving erythematous ulcerations.

These findings are consistent with herpes genitalis, most likely caused by infection with herpes simplex virus type 2.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with condylomata acuminata, which are genital warts caused by HPV. HPV vaccines are recommended by the CDC to all persons aged 9–26 years and are most effective before exposure to HPV via sexual activity; they are routinely administered at 11–12 years of age. The tetravalent and 9-valent vaccines provide ∼ 99% coverage against the types of HPV most commonly implicated in genital warts (types 6 and 11) and in cervical cancer (especially types 16 and 18) for at least 10 years after vaccination (likely longer, but data is only available for that time period). Given this patient's sexual history, HPV vaccine would most likely have prevented this condition.

Some older HPV vaccines (e.g., Cervarix®) do not cover the types of HPV associated with genital warts (types 6 and 11) and only protect against cervical cancer.
Image Description:

Photograph of the perianal region of a child with HIV (image rotated: gluteal cleft runs from upper right to lower left of image)

Multiple flesh-colored papules with a folded irregular surface have formed a plaque in the perianal region.

Immunodeficiency (e.g., due to HIV infection) increases both the risk of HPV infection becoming symptomatic (in this case with anogenital warts) and the severity of symptoms
questions.hint: In a sexually active adolescent, the presence of multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules indicates human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.

questions.text:
A healthy 6-month-old girl is brought in for a well-child visit and receives the following vaccines:

Diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis

Haemophilus influenzae type b
Inactivated poliovirus
Rotavirus
Pneumococcal conjugate
Inactivated influenza vaccine

She has received all prior recommended vaccinations. At what age should this patient receive her next dose of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) should be administered as a routine vaccination at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.

B) INCORRECT:

The diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) should be administered as a routine vaccination at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.

C) INCORRECT:

The diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) should be administered as a routine vaccination at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.

D) INCORRECT:

The diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) should be administered as a routine vaccination at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.

E) CORRECT:

All children should receive vaccines to prevent diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis. Diphtheria is spread via person-to-person contact and causes a thick, membranous covering in the back of the throat that can lead to breathing problems. Pertussis is also spread via person-to-person contact and causes whooping cough; infection in the first year of life, particularly in unimmunized children, is associated with high risk of morbidity and mortality. Tetanus, which is acquired through cuts and wounds, causes painful tightening of the muscles.

The diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) should be administered as a routine vaccination at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years. This patient, who is 6 months old, should receive her next dose of DTaP at 15 to 18 months of age. Children can receive the fourth dose of DTaP vaccine as early as 12 months of age, as long as 6 months have elapsed since receipt of the third dose.

The vaccine can be given during mild illness, such as a cold, but may be postponed for moderate-to-severe illness.

The vaccine should not be given to patients who have had a life-threatening allergic reaction to a previous dose or to any of the vaccine components. It also should not be given to patients who have had encephalopathy not attributable to another identifiable cause (e.g., coma, decreased level of consciousness, prolonged seizures within 7 days of being given a previous dose of DTaP or another pertussis-containing vaccine).

Key learning point: Diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine should be given at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman asks whether she is eligible to receive vaccination against herpes zoster (shingles). Her medical history is significant for one episode of herpes zoster 10 years ago on her right flank, rheumatoid arthritis that is well controlled with prednisone, and insulin-requiring type 2 diabetes with fasting blood glucose levels ranging from 180 mg/dL to 250 mg/dL (reference range for diabetes, > 125 mg/dL). Her last glycated hemoglobin level was 9%. What is the most appropriate answer to this patient’s question?

choices.text: She is ineligible to receive the recombinant zoster vaccine because of her prednisone use
She is ineligible to receive the recombinant zoster vaccine because of her prior episode of shingles
She can receive the recombinant zoster vaccine after her diabetes is better controlled
She is eligible to receive the recombinant zoster vaccine
She is ineligible to receive the recombinant zoster vaccine because she is older than age 60

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Taking immunosuppressive therapy, such as prednisone, does not impact a patient's eligibility for the recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV).

B) INCORRECT:

A prior history of herpes zoster does not affect a patient's eligibility for the RZV, although the vaccine should not be administered until after any active episode has resolved.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic medical conditions, including diabetes mellitus, do not affect a patient's eligibility for the RZV, regardless of the level of control of the condition.

D) CORRECT:

Herpes zoster vaccination reduces the incidence of herpes zoster (shingles) and the incidence and severity of postherpetic neuralgia. The recombinant zoster vaccine (RZV) is recommended for all individuals aged ≥50 years (with no upper age limit) and for individuals ≥19 years who are or will be immunocompromised. It should be administered in two doses spaced 2 to 6 months apart.

RZV can be administered safely to adults with a prior history of herpes zoster (although the vaccine should not be administered until after any active episode has resolved) and to adults with chronic medical conditions, including diabetes mellitus and rheumatoid arthritis.

The zoster vaccine live (ZVL), which was contraindicated in patients with significant immunosuppression, is no longer available. Individuals who previously received this vaccine can safely receive two doses of RZV as long as the first dose is administered at least 2 months after receipt of ZVL.

Key learning point: Herpes zoster vaccination with the recombinant zoster vaccine is recommended for all people aged ≥50 years, regardless of whether they have a previous history of herpes zoster, and also for individuals aged ≥19 years who are or will be immunodeficient or immunosuppressed.

E) INCORRECT:

Age greater than 60 does not make someone ineligible for the RZV.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the office for a routine pelvic examination. She feels well. Menses occur at 30-day intervals and last 7 days. Her last menstrual period was 6 days ago. Her last Pap smear was 13 months ago and there is no history of abnormal findings. She is sexually active with three male partners and uses condoms consistently. She has never been tested for sexually transmitted infections. Her 54-year-old mother has breast cancer. She did not receive a human papillomavirus vaccine. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. In addition to HIV, gonorrhea, chlamydia, and syphilis testing, which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

As part of the routine immunization schedule, the CDC states that two doses of the nine-valent human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine should be administered six months apart to all individuals aged 9–14 years. For all unvaccinated female individuals aged 15–26 years, the CDC recommends vaccination with three doses of the nine-valent HPV vaccine at 0, 2, and 6 months. The HPV vaccine is approved by the FDA for individuals up to the age of 45 years, but it is not routinely recommended by the CDC for individuals aged > 26 years.

Condoms lower the risk of, but do not protect against, HPV infection because HPV can still be transmitted via genital skin-to-skin contact or oral sex.

B) INCORRECT:

For women aged between 21 and 29 years, the USPSTF recommends a Pap smear every three years. Since this patient had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago, another Pap smear is not required for nearly another two years.

C) INCORRECT:

The most common indication for a pregnancy test is recent-onset secondary amenorrhea in a patient of childbearing age. Because her last menstrual period was six days ago, this patient does not have amenorrhea. If this 24-year-old woman had acute lower abdominal pain, a pregnancy test would be indicated to rule out an ectopic pregnancy. However, there is currently no indication for performing a pregnancy test in this asymptomatic patient presenting for a routine pelvic examination.

D) INCORRECT:

Cotesting refers to simultaneous Pap smear and HPV testing. It is the USPSTF's recommended cervical cancer screening of choice for women aged between 30 and 65 years every five years. In this 24-year-old patient, the USPSTF instead recommends a Pap smear every three years. Unfortunately, cancer screening recommendations can be confusing because the USPSTF guidelines differ from the recently updated ASCCP/ACS/ACOG guidelines, which recommend that women aged 25–65 years should undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing (preferred where available) every five years, cotesting (HPV testing and Pap smear) every five years, or a solitary Pap smear every three years. But this patient is not yet 25 years of age and also had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago. Regardless, if the information required to determine the correct option for NBME questions is associated with a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF guidelines.

E) INCORRECT:

HPV testing and a simultaneous Pap smear, known as cotesting, is recommended by the USPSTF for cervical cancer screening for patients aged 30–65 years every five years. Unfortunately, cancer screening recommendations can be confusing because the USPSTF guidelines differ from the recently updated ASCCP/ACS/ACOG guidelines, which recommend women aged 25–65 years should undergo cervical cancer screening with primary HPV testing alone (preferred where available) every five years, cotesting (HPV testing and Pap smear) every five years, or a solitary Pap smear every three years. But this patient is not yet 25 years of age and also had a normal Pap smear 13 months ago. Regardless, if the information required to determine the correct option for NBME questions is associated with a discrepancy between screening guidelines, we recommend following USPSTF guidelines.
questions.hint: This patient's history and age determine the most appropriate recommendation at this time.

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy is brought to the office by his parents for a well-child examination. He has cystic fibrosis diagnosed by newborn screening. His parents report frequent feedings and large-volume, greasy stools. Current medications include bronchodilators, pancreatic enzyme supplements, and fat-soluble vitamins. He is at the 18th percentile for height and 15th percentile for weight. Auscultation of the lungs discloses diffuse wheezes. Examination shows a distended and tympanic abdomen with no tenderness or guarding. Which of the following would be a contraindication for administering one or more routine vaccinations in this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Developing a fever after vaccination is not a contraindication for subsequent vaccinations. Although developing a fever of ≥ 40.5°C (105.0°F) within 48 hours of receiving DTaP was previously a contraindication for subsequent DTaP vaccinations, it is now considered safe to administer the vaccine. Moderate to severe acute illness, with or without fever at the time of vaccination, is a precaution rather than a contraindication for most vaccines.

B) INCORRECT:

Cystic fibrosis is not a contraindication for any vaccines. If possible, patients with cystic fibrosis should always be up-to-date with their vaccinations to prevent complications.

C) INCORRECT:

A history of severe allergic reaction (i.e., anaphylaxis) to a previous dose of the vaccine or any of its components is a contraindication for any particular vaccine. However, a history of egg protein allergy without severe reaction to a vaccine is not a contraindication for egg protein-containing vaccines (e.g., flu vaccine) according to the Centers for Disease Control. Moreover, none of the routine immunizations scheduled at 4 months (rotavirus, DTaP, Hib, PCV, and IPV) contain egg proteins.

D) INCORRECT:

Certain unstable neurological disorders (e.g., uncontrolled epilepsy, infantile spasms, progressive encephalopathy) are contraindications for the pertussis vaccine, which is part of the DTaP vaccine. However, niether stable neurological disorders (e.g., controlled epilepsy), nor resolved neurological disorders, nor a history of uncomplicated febrile seizures are contraindications for any of the standard childhood vaccines.

E) CORRECT:

Individuals with cystic fibrosis are at increased risk of developing intussusception. Although data is conflicting, a history of intussusception is considered a contraindication for receiving the rotavirus vaccine according to the Centers for Disease Control (CDC). The exact mechanism by which the rotavirus vaccine leads to intussusception is unknown. Some studies suggest that since the introduction of the rotavirus vaccine the overall incidence of intussusception has not risen but the average age of onset in infants has decreased.

According to the CDC, other contraindications to the rotavirus vaccine are severe combined immunodeficiency and severe allergic reactions (i.e., anaphylaxis) to a previous dose of the vaccine.
questions.hint: This 4-month-old patient should receive his routine immunizations, including diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, acellular pertussis (DTaP), Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), inactivated poliovirus (IPV), pneumococcal conjugate, and rotavirus vaccines, the latter of which is contraindicated by one of the conditions listed below.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the office in June for a routine check-up. She has chronic back pain. Her last mammogram was 6 months ago and showed no abnormalities. Her last Pap smear was 2 years ago and unremarkable. A colonoscopy 5 years ago was normal. She takes a multivitamin daily and uses topical steroids. Her immunization records show that she has never received a pneumococcal or a shingles vaccine, her last tetanus booster was 6 years ago, and her last influenza vaccine was 2 years ago. BMI is 26 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most appropriate recommendation at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Osteoporosis screening is performed with dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DXA). The bone density scan is recommended for postmenopausal women older than 65 years of age, or younger postmenopausal women with a pathological fracture or other risk factors for osteoporosis (e.g., positive family history).

B) INCORRECT:

The CDC recommends pneumococcal vaccination for adults ≥ 50 years of age. However, the polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) is typically recommended after administering a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine, which this patient has not yet received.

C) INCORRECT:

A Pap smear is recommended every 3 years in women 21–65 years of age (or even better for patients 30–65 years of age, HPV/Pap cotesting every 5 years). This woman had a normal Pap smear 2 years ago.

D) INCORRECT:

Because influenza viruses are constantly evolving, the influenza vaccine composition is reviewed, and a newly updated vaccine is released (and recommended) for every flu season (∼ Oct.–Apr. in the northern hemisphere). This patient should return again in the early fall for an influenza vaccine.

E) CORRECT:

The CDC currently recommends the recombinant zoster vaccine for the prevention of herpes zoster (shingles) and its related complications. The recombinant zoster vaccine (administered in 2 doses, 2–6 months apart) is recommended for all immunocompetent adults ≥ 50 years of age, regardless of a history of shingles, and for adults ≥ 19 years of age who are or will become immunodeficient or immunosuppressed due to disease or therapy.

Additionally, this individual should receive pneumococcal vaccination with a pneumococcal conjugate vaccine.
questions.hint: The correct choice is recommended in all patients over 50 years by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and a 14-year history of mild-to-moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, as defined by the Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease stages, presents in the late fall for routine follow-up. His current medications are inhaled albuterol as needed and metformin. He has a 30-pack-year history of cigarette smoking but quit 13 years ago. He received an influenza immunization one year ago and is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations. He has also received the 15-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine followed by the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine. Which of the following immunization plans for influenza and pneumococcal disease is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine and 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine
Inactivated influenza vaccine and 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine
Intranasal live influenza vaccine and 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If a person receives PCV15, it should be followed by a dose of 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23). The 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13) is no longer recommended. This patient is up to date on his pneumococcal vaccination and should receive only the influenza vaccine at this visit.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient is up to date on his pneumococcal vaccination and should receive only the influenza vaccine at this visit.

C) CORRECT:

This patient is up to date on his pneumococcal vaccination and should receive only the inactivated influenza vaccine at this visit. Annual influenza immunization is recommended for all individuals over 6 months of age. Adult patients who are eligible for pneumococcal vaccination should receive one dose of 15-, 20-, or 21-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV15, PCV20, or PCV21). If a person receives PCV15, it should be followed by a dose of 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23), usually at least one year later; PPSV23 is not needed if the patient receives PCV20 or PCV21.

Key learning point: Patients of any age with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease should receive pneumococcal vaccination and an annual influenza vaccine.

D) INCORRECT:

The nasal spray influenza vaccine containing live attenuated virus can be used in individuals 2 to 49 years of age who are not pregnant and who do not have immunosuppression or other high-risk medical conditions. Individuals aged ≥ 50 years should receive the inactivated influenza vaccine.

E) INCORRECT:

The nasal spray influenza vaccine containing live attenuated virus can be used in individuals 2 to 49 years of age who are not pregnant and who do not have immunosuppression or other high-risk medical conditions. Individuals aged ≥ 50 years should receive the inactivated influenza vaccine. Moreover, this patient is up to date on his pneumococcal vaccination.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman comes to the office for preconception counseling. She reports that she has been trying to conceive with her husband for 2 months. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last 4 days with normal flow. She did not receive the MMR vaccine when she was young because of an “egg allergy.” Her vaccinations are otherwise up-to-date. Her only medication is a daily folic acid supplement. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count is within the reference range. Her serum human chorionic gonadotropin concentration is 3 mIU/mL (N ≤ 5). Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain rectal swab for group B streptococcus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Iron supplementation (30–60 mg/day) is indicated in maternal iron deficiency anemia. Iron deficiency anemia can increase the risk of placental insufficiency and is the most common type of anemia in pregnancy. Iron supplementation is not needed if anemia is not present; this patient's complete blood count is within range.

B) CORRECT:

As part of comprehensive preconception care, physicians should assess individuals' immunization status and recommend all routine age-appropriate immunizations. Because of the risk of congenital abnormalities following infection with rubella or varicella in pregnancy, the MMR and varicella vaccines are especially recommended. In patients with no evidence of immunity to rubella (e.g., those who did not receive the MMR vaccine), rubella antibody testing should be used to screen for immunity, and vaccination should be recommended in individuals without immunity. The MMR and varicella vaccines are live vaccines, which are contraindicated during pregnancy due to the potential risk of infection in the birthing parent and consequent vertical transmission. Accordingly, conception should be avoided for 1–3 months after immunization.

In the past, administering the MMR vaccine to children with egg allergies raised concerns because of residual egg proteins in the vaccine. However, the MMR vaccine is currently considered safe for children with egg allergy.

C) INCORRECT:

Group B streptococcus (GBS) infection can cause chorioamnionitis, neonatal meningitis, sepsis, and pneumonia; vaginal and rectal swab for gram stain and culture can detect GBS. However, GBS screening is indicated at 36 0/7– 37 6/7 weeks of gestation rather than before conception.

D) INCORRECT:

Screening for chlamydia infection is recommended in all sexually active women < 25 years of age and all women who are at increased risk for a sexually transmitted infection (e.g., having more than one sex partner, using condoms inconsistently outside a mutually monogamous relationship, performing sex in exchange for money). This patient does not have any risk factors for chlamydia infection, so she does not need to be screened for it. All pregnant women should be screened for hepatitis B, hepatitis C, HIV, and syphilis at the initial examination (∼ 10 weeks gestation).

E) INCORRECT:

A 1-hour oral glucose challenge test is used to screen for gestational diabetes mellitus. Potential complications of pregestational diabetes mellitus include gestational hypertension, preeclampsia, eclampsia, urinary tract infections, and fetal diabetic fetopathy. A 1-hour glucose challenge is indicated at 24–28 weeks of gestation; this patient's normal serum β-hCG concentration indicates that she is currently not pregnant. A hemoglobin A1C test would be used to detect pregestational diabetes mellitus.
questions.hint: This patient has a normal serum β-hCG concentration, which indicates that she is not currently pregnant. Many diseases increase the risk to the fetus and birthing parent. However, certain diseases can be devastating to the fetus and are ideally addressed prior to conception.

questions.text:
A 2-month-old male infant, born at 30 weeks’ gestation, is brought to a routine check-up. He spent 4 weeks in the NICU for prematurity-related complications but has been stable since discharge. His mother is concerned about vaccinating him 'on time' due to his prematurity and lower weight compared to term infants. Physical examination is normal, and his growth trajectory is appropriate for his gestational age.
Which of the following is the most appropriate approach to this infant’s routine immunizations?

choices.text: Follow the usual recommended schedule based on chronological age
Administer vaccines only after achieving a weight above 5 kg
Use half-dose immunizations until growth parameters normalize
Delay vaccine administration until 2 months corrected gestational age

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Immunization guidelines for preterm infants recommend using chronological age, not corrected gestational age or weight, for vaccine administration. Preterm infants develop adequate immune responses when vaccinated according to their actual age. Timely vaccinations are crucial to protect against serious infections, as premature infants are at higher risk for complications from vaccine-preventable diseases. The standard dosing regimen is appropriate, and modifications based on weight or corrected age are not supported by evidence. Adhering to the standard schedule ensures timely and effective protection.

Key learning point: Preterm infants should receive vaccines according to their chronological age, following the usual immunization schedule and dose, to ensure adequate protection against infections.

B) INCORRECT:

Vaccination schedules are based on chronological age, not weight. Preterm infants, despite lower weights, should receive vaccines on schedule once clinically stable. Waiting for a specific weight, like 5 kg, is not evidence-based and delays protection against preventable diseases.

C) INCORRECT:

Preterm infants should receive full-dose immunizations based on chronological age. Full antigenic doses are necessary for adequate immune response. Reduced doses may compromise immunogenicity and are not supported by immunization guidelines.

D) INCORRECT:

Immunizations are scheduled based on chronological age, not corrected gestational age. Preterm infants develop adequate immune responses when vaccinated at the same ages as term infants. Delaying vaccines based on corrected age prolongs vulnerability to diseases.

questions.text: A healthy 2-day-old infant, born in a high TB-burden region, is ready for discharge. Which is the most appropriate immediate vaccination?

choices.text: Defer all vaccinations until 2 months of age

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The BCG vaccine is essential in high tuberculosis-burden regions to protect against severe TB forms. However, neonatal immunization schedules often include both BCG and hepatitis B vaccines to address multiple infectious risks. Administering only the BCG vaccine does not provide comprehensive protection against hepatitis B, which is also a significant concern.

B) CORRECT:

In high tuberculosis-burden regions, neonatal vaccination protocols prioritize early immunization to protect against significant infectious risks. The Bacillus Calmette-Guérin (BCG) vaccine is recommended to reduce the risk of severe tuberculosis manifestations, such as miliary TB and TB meningitis, in infancy. The hepatitis B vaccine is administered shortly after birth to prevent perinatal transmission and establish early immunity against hepatitis B virus infection. Administering both vaccines during the neonatal period ensures comprehensive protection against these prevalent infectious threats.

Key learning point: Before discharge, a newborn should receive the Hepatitis B vaccine, and in certain regions, the BCG vaccine is also administered to protect against tuberculosis.

C) INCORRECT:

The hepatitis B vaccine is crucial for preventing vertical transmission of hepatitis B virus, especially in infants born to mothers with hepatitis B infection. However, in a high tuberculosis-burden region, the immediate need also includes protection against tuberculosis. The absence of specific risk factors for hepatitis B transmission in this scenario makes the hepatitis B vaccine alone less appropriate as the immediate vaccination.

D) INCORRECT:

Deferring all vaccinations until 2 months of age delays critical immunologic protection. In high tuberculosis-burden regions, early administration of vaccines like BCG and hepatitis B is crucial to protect against severe infections during a vulnerable period. This approach contradicts guidelines that emphasize early vaccination to mitigate immediate infectious risks.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy with HIV is brought to the clinic for a routine check-up. He has no history of varicella infection and has not received the varicella vaccine. His most recent laboratory testing shows a CD4 count of 180 cells/mm³. Physical examination is normal, and his other vaccinations are up to date. His mother is concerned about potential exposure to chickenpox at school.
What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding varicella vaccination in this patient?

choices.text: Give prophylactic acyclovir and proceed with vaccination
Obtain varicella IgG testing and vaccinate if negative
Defer varicella vaccination while significant immunosuppression persists

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic acyclovir may inhibit the replication of the vaccine strain, leading to an inadequate immune response. Live vaccines in HIV-infected children require a CD4 count of 200 cells/mm³ or higher for safety and efficacy. Acyclovir does not mitigate the risks associated with live vaccination in immunocompromised patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Live-attenuated vaccines require sufficient immune competence for safe administration. In HIV-infected individuals, vaccination with live vaccines is recommended only when the CD4 count is at least 200 cells/mm³. This patient's CD4 count of 180 cells/mm³ indicates significant immunosuppression, posing a risk for disseminated infection from the vaccine strain.

C) INCORRECT:

Varicella IgG testing can determine immunity status, but in HIV patients with a CD4 count below 200 cells/mm³, live vaccines are contraindicated due to the risk of vaccine-induced disease. A negative IgG result does not alter the contraindication imposed by severe immunosuppression.

D) CORRECT:

Live attenuated vaccines, such as the varicella vaccine, require an intact immune response to control viral replication. In HIV-infected patients with severe immunosuppression, indicated by a CD4 count below 200 cells/mm³, there is an increased risk of vaccine-induced disease. This threshold reflects the immune competency needed for safe administration of live vaccines. Adhering to vaccination guidelines ensures that live vaccines are deferred until immune function improves, minimizing adverse outcomes.

Key learning point: Live vaccines, such as the varicella vaccine, are contraindicated in patients with significant immunosuppression, including those with low T-cell counts due to HIV infection.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman at 20 weeks’ gestation presents to the Outpatient Clinic in early October for routine prenatal care. She is concerned about contracting influenza. Her immunization records are incomplete, with no documented influenza vaccine within the past year. She is unsure about having experienced rubella in childhood. Vital signs are normal, and physical examination is unremarkable.
Which of the following is the most appropriate immunization recommendation for this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The varicella vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine and is contraindicated during pregnancy due to the risk of fetal harm, including congenital varicella syndrome. Vaccination is deferred until the postpartum period for women lacking immunity.

B) CORRECT:

Pregnant women are at increased risk for severe influenza due to physiological and immunologic changes. The inactivated influenza vaccine, administered intramuscularly, is safe at any stage of pregnancy and reduces maternal morbidity and adverse neonatal outcomes. Immunization during pregnancy also provides passive immunity to the infant, protecting them during early life. The vaccine's safety and effectiveness make it the recommended strategy for preventing influenza in pregnant patients.

Key learning point: The influenza vaccine is recommended during pregnancy to protect both the mother and the fetus, while live attenuated vaccines such as rubella, measles, and varicella are contraindicated during pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Live attenuated vaccines, such as the intranasal influenza vaccine, are contraindicated in pregnancy due to the theoretical risk of fetal harm from the replication-competent virus. The inactivated influenza vaccine is preferred for pregnant women due to its established safety profile.

D) INCORRECT:

The MMR (measles, mumps, and rubella) vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine and is contraindicated during pregnancy due to the risk of fetal transmission. Although the patient's rubella immunity is uncertain, the focus is on influenza prevention, and live vaccines are deferred until postpartum.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old G2P1 woman at 24 weeks’ gestation visits the Outpatient Clinic in September for a routine prenatal exam. She has a history of mild asthma and recalls a mild reaction to a flu shot in the past. She is otherwise healthy with no known allergies. Her immunization history shows she missed the varicella vaccination as a child. She is concerned about contracting infections.
Which of the following vaccines is most appropriate to administer now?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The rubella vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine and is contraindicated during pregnancy due to the theoretical risk of fetal exposure and teratogenic effects. Live vaccines are deferred until the postpartum period, and only vaccines with established safety profiles are administered during pregnancy.

B) INCORRECT:

The varicella vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine and is contraindicated during pregnancy due to the risk of fetal transmission and potential adverse effects, such as congenital varicella syndrome. Live vaccines are deferred until the postpartum period.

C) INCORRECT:

Live attenuated vaccines, like the live attenuated influenza vaccine, are contraindicated during pregnancy due to the theoretical risk of fetal infection from transplacental viral transmission. The inactivated influenza vaccine is preferred for pregnant patients, regardless of a history of mild reactions to flu shots.

D) CORRECT:

The inactivated influenza vaccine is recommended during pregnancy due to its safety and efficacy in protecting both the mother and newborn. Pregnancy increases susceptibility to severe influenza due to altered pulmonary function and immune adaptations. The inactivated vaccine contains no live virus, making it safe at any gestational age. It also facilitates passive antibody transfer to the fetus, providing early protection during infancy.

Key learning point: The influenza vaccine is recommended for pregnant women during any trimester to protect against the flu, while live vaccines like rubella and varicella are contraindicated during pregnancy.

questions.text: You are seeing a 7-year-old boy in the emergency department who presents with a 1-day history of involuntary muscle contractions and pain in his back and neck. Two weeks ago, he fell while playing in a sandbox and scraped his knees. He has not received any vaccinations since birth. His temperature is 38.5°C. He is diaphoretic. On examination, he is unable to open his mouth beyond 1 cm, has hyperextension of the lumbar spine, and shows resistance to neck flexion. Which one of the following, if administered, would most likely have prevented his current condition?

choices.text: Human immunoglobulin against a viral protein.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Denatured C. tetani toxoid is used as a vaccination against tetanus. The still-intact receptor binding site of the toxoid induces antibody production and memory cell formation (active immunity). In patients with dirty wounds and incomplete or unclear tetanus immunization status, postexposure prophylaxis should include vaccination with DTaP and administration of human tetanus immunoglobulin (HTIG). Management of tetanus includes antibiotic therapy and intensive care treatment.

Key learning point: The tetanus vaccine is a denatured (inactivated) bacterial toxoid that induces active immunity and prevents tetanus infection.
Image Description:

This diagram illustrates vaccine types based on the example of antiviral vaccines.

Traditional vaccines are either live attenuated or inactivated. Live attenuated vaccines contain modified whole virus particles capable of replication, but not of causing disease. Inactivated vaccines contain either the whole inactivated virus particles or their subunits.

Gene-based vaccines contain only the genetic information of the pathogen. This information, which is transmitted either directly in the form of nucleic acid (DNA in a recombinant plasmid or mRNA in a lipid envelope) or by means of a recombinant viral vector, induces endogenous antigen production in the host cells.

B) INCORRECT:

Capsular polysaccharide vaccines contain purified capsule antigens that are usually conjugated to a carrier protein (conjugate vaccine). Such vaccines are used to prevent infection with, e.g., S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae type b, and N. meningitidis, all of which can cause meningitis. Although meningitis can present with fever and neck stiffness, trismus and opisthotonus are not characteristic features. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.

C) INCORRECT:

Human immunoglobulin against a viral protein is used for post-exposure prophylaxis in suspected cases of rabies. Administering preformed antibodies provides a passive immunity that, however, does not last long due to the antibodies' short half-life. Even though patients with rabies can present with trismus, opisthotonus, and symptoms of autonomic hyperactivity, as seen in this patient, they also present with other characteristic features like hydrophobia and agitation. Furthermore, this patient has no history of an animal bite (e.g., by a bat or raccoon) that would raise suspicion for transmission of rabies. In post-exposure prophylaxis of tetanus, which is caused by a bacterium, not a virus, human tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) is used against tetanus toxin.

D) INCORRECT:

Chemically-inactivated (whole-cell) viruses have been used as vaccines to prevent, e.g., polio (Salk vaccine), hepatitis A, and influenza virus infections. However, this patient presents with symptoms of tetanus. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.

E) INCORRECT:

Viable but weakened microorganisms are used in live attenuated vaccines for the prevention of, e.g., measles, mumps, rubella, varicella zoster, and rotavirus infection. These vaccines induce both cellular and humoral immune responses. However, this patient presents with symptoms of tetanus. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.
questions.hint: Generalized muscle spasms (trismus, mild opisthotonus, nuchal rigidity) and symptoms of autonomic hyperactivity (fever, sweating) following a cutaneous injury in an unvaccinated child suggest tetanus, which is diagnosed clinically.

questions.text:
You are seeing a healthy 6-month-old girl for a well-child visit. She receives the following vaccines during this visit:

Diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis

Haemophilus influenzae type b
Inactivated poliovirus
Rotavirus
Pneumococcal conjugate
Inactivated influenza vaccine

She has received all prior recommended vaccinations. At what age should she receive her next dose of diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) should be administered as a routine vaccination at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.

B) CORRECT:

All children should receive vaccines to prevent diphtheria, tetanus, and pertussis. Diphtheria is spread via person-to-person contact and causes a thick, membranous covering in the back of the throat that can lead to breathing problems. Pertussis is also spread via person-to-person contact and causes whooping cough; infection in the first year of life, particularly in unimmunized children, is associated with high risk of morbidity and mortality. Tetanus, which is acquired through cuts and wounds, causes painful tightening of the muscles.

The diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) should be administered as a routine vaccination at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years. This patient, who is 6 months old, should receive her next dose of DTaP at 15 to 18 months of age. Children can receive the fourth dose of DTaP vaccine as early as 12 months of age, as long as 6 months have elapsed since receipt of the third dose.

The vaccine can be given during mild illness, such as a cold, but may be postponed for moderate-to-severe illness.

The vaccine should not be given to patients who have had a life-threatening allergic reaction to a previous dose or to any of the vaccine components. It also should not be given to patients who have had encephalopathy not attributable to another identifiable cause (e.g., coma, decreased level of consciousness, prolonged seizures within 7 days of being given a previous dose of DTaP or another pertussis-containing vaccine).

Key learning point: Diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine should be given at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.

C) INCORRECT:

The diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) should be administered as a routine vaccination at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.

D) INCORRECT:

The diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) should be administered as a routine vaccination at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.

E) INCORRECT:

The diphtheria-tetanus-acellular pertussis vaccine (DTaP) should be administered as a routine vaccination at the following ages: 2 months, 4 months, 6 months, 15 to 18 months, and 4 to 6 years.

questions.text: You are seeing a 56-year-old man with type 2 diabetes and a 14-year history of mild-to-moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), as defined by the Global Initiative for Chronic Obstructive Lung Disease stages, for routine follow-up in late fall. His current medications are inhaled albuterol as needed and metformin. He has a 30-pack-year smoking history but quit 13 years ago. He received an influenza vaccine one year ago and is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations. He has also received the 15-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine followed by the 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine. Which one of the following immunization plans for influenza and pneumococcal disease is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Inactivated influenza vaccine and 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine.
23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine and 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine.
Intranasal live influenza vaccine and 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient is up to date on his pneumococcal vaccination and should receive only the influenza vaccine at this visit.

B) INCORRECT:

The nasal spray influenza vaccine containing live attenuated virus can be used in individuals 2 to 49 years of age who are not pregnant and who do not have immunosuppression or other high-risk medical conditions. Individuals aged ≥ 50 years should receive the inactivated influenza vaccine.

C) INCORRECT:

If a person receives PCV15, it should be followed by a dose of 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23). The 13-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV13) is no longer recommended. This patient is up to date on his pneumococcal vaccination and should receive only the influenza vaccine at this visit.

D) CORRECT:

This patient is up to date on his pneumococcal vaccination and should receive only the inactivated influenza vaccine at this visit. Annual influenza immunization is recommended for all individuals over 6 months of age. Adult patients who are eligible for pneumococcal vaccination should receive one dose of 15-, 20-, or 21-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV15, PCV20, or PCV21). If a person receives PCV15, it should be followed by a dose of 23-valent pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23), usually at least one year later; PPSV23 is not needed if the patient receives PCV20 or PCV21.
