Key learning point: Patients of any age with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease should receive pneumococcal vaccination and an annual influenza vaccine.

E) INCORRECT:

The nasal spray influenza vaccine containing live attenuated virus can be used in individuals 2 to 49 years of age who are not pregnant and who do not have immunosuppression or other high-risk medical conditions. Individuals aged ≥ 50 years should receive the inactivated influenza vaccine. Moreover, this patient is up to date on his pneumococcal vaccination.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of genital lesions. She has no history of serious illness. She is sexually active with two male partners and uses condoms inconsistently. Vital signs are normal. On pelvic examination, there are multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules over the vulva. The lesions turn white with application of 3% acetic acid. Which one of the following is most likely to have prevented this condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

HIV can present with genital lesions in a sexually active individual. Molluscum contagiosum, which is a common genital lesion in adults associated with HIV, could present with a nontender, exophytic papule on the genitalia. However, these lesions would have a characteristic hemispherical, umbilicated appearance, and they would not turn white on application of 3% acetic acid. Moreover, there are no other features in this patient that suggest immunocompromise, which is typical of HIV.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with condylomata acuminata, which are genital warts caused by HPV. The 2024 National Advisory Committee on Immunization guidelines strongly recommend routine 9‑valent HPV vaccination for all individuals aged 9–26 years, with optimal protection achieved when the vaccine is administered before the onset of sexual activity. The tetravalent and 9-valent vaccines provide ∼ 99% coverage against the types of HPV most commonly implicated in genital warts (types 6 and 11) and cervical cancer (especially types 16 and 18) for at least 10 years after vaccination (likely longer, but data is only available for that time). Some older HPV vaccines (e.g., Cervarix®) do not cover the types of HPV associated with genital warts (types 6 and 11) and only protect against cervical cancer. Given this patient's sexual history, the HPV vaccine would most likely have prevented this condition.

Key learning point: HPV vaccination is the most effective strategy to prevent genital warts and related HPV-associated diseases.
Image Description:

Photograph of the perianal region of a child with HIV (image rotated: gluteal cleft runs from upper right to lower left of image)

Multiple flesh-colored papules with a folded irregular surface have formed a plaque in the perianal region.

Immunodeficiency (e.g., due to HIV infection) increases both the risk of HPV infection becoming symptomatic (in this case with anogenital warts) and the severity of symptoms

C) INCORRECT:

Famciclovir is used for the treatment and prophylaxis of genital herpes caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV-1 or HSV-2). A case of genital herpes could present with multiple raised lesions over the vulva. However, the lesions would be vesicular or ulcerative, very painful, and associated with systemic features (like fever, lymphadenopathy, etc.), which are not seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Although condom use may help reduce the risk of HPV transmission, studies have shown that contact with uncovered areas still allows for HPV transmission. Condom use is therefore not the best option for preventing this patient's condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Spermicidal foams and gels are means of contraception with medium efficacy and may be used by sexually active individuals who do not intend to get pregnant. However, they do not provide any protection against sexually transmitted infections, such as the one in this case.
questions.hint: In a sexually active adolescent, the presence of multiple hyperkeratotic exophytic papules indicates human papillomavirus (HPV) infection.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-month-old boy in your clinic for a well-child examination. He has cystic fibrosis diagnosed by newborn screening. His parents report that he feeds frequently and has large-volume, greasy stools. His current medications include bronchodilators, pancreatic enzyme supplements, and fat-soluble vitamins. His height is at the 18th percentile and his weight is at the 15th percentile. On lung auscultation, there are diffuse wheezes. Abdominal examination reveals a distended and tympanic abdomen without tenderness or guarding. Which one of the following would be a contraindication to administering one or more routine vaccinations to this patient at this time?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Developing a fever after vaccination is not a contraindication for subsequent vaccinations. Although developing a fever of ≥ 40.5°C (105.0°F) within 48 hours of receiving DTaP was previously a contraindication for subsequent DTaP vaccinations, it is now considered safe to administer the vaccine. Moderate to severe acute illness, with or without fever at the time of vaccination, is a precaution rather than a contraindication for most vaccines.

B) CORRECT:

Individuals with cystic fibrosis are at increased risk of developing intussusception. Although data is conflicting, a history of intussusception is considered a contraindication for receiving the rotavirus vaccine according to the National Advisory Committee on Immunization. The exact mechanism by which the rotavirus vaccine leads to intussusception is unknown. Some studies suggest that since the introduction of the rotavirus vaccine the overall incidence of intussusception has not risen but the average age of onset in infants has decreased.

Other contraindications to the rotavirus vaccine are severe combined immunodeficiency and severe allergic reactions (i.e., anaphylaxis) to a previous dose of the vaccine.

Key learning point: A history of intussusception is a contraindication to administering the rotavirus vaccine in infants.

C) INCORRECT:

Certain unstable neurological disorders (e.g., uncontrolled epilepsy, infantile spasms, progressive encephalopathy) are contraindications for the pertussis vaccine, which is part of the DTaP vaccine. However, niether stable neurological disorders (e.g., controlled epilepsy), nor resolved neurological disorders, nor a history of uncomplicated febrile seizures are contraindications for any of the standard childhood vaccines.

D) INCORRECT:

A history of severe allergic reaction (i.e., anaphylaxis) to a previous dose of the vaccine or any of its components is a contraindication for any particular vaccine. However, a history of egg protein allergy without severe reaction to a vaccine is not a contraindication for egg protein-containing vaccines (e.g., flu vaccine) according to the National Advisory Committee on Immunization. Moreover, none of the routine immunizations scheduled at 4 months (rotavirus, DTaP, Hib, PCV, and IPV) contain egg proteins.

E) INCORRECT:

Cystic fibrosis is not a contraindication for any vaccines. If possible, patients with cystic fibrosis should always be up-to-date with their vaccinations to prevent complications.
questions.hint: This 4-month-old patient should receive his routine immunizations, including diphtheria and tetanus toxoids, acellular pertussis (DTaP), Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib), inactivated poliovirus (IPV), pneumococcal conjugate, and rotavirus vaccines, the latter of which is contraindicated by one of the conditions listed below.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to your clinic for preconception counseling. She and her husband have been trying to conceive for 2 months. Her menstrual cycles are regular, occurring every 30 days and lasting 4 days with normal flow. She did not receive the MMR vaccine in childhood due to a reported “egg allergy.” All other vaccinations are up to date. Her only medication is a daily folic acid supplement. Vital signs are normal. Physical examination is normal. A complete blood count is within the reference range. Her serum human chorionic gonadotropin concentration is 3 IU/L (<5). Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain rectal swab for group B streptococcus.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A 1-hour oral glucose challenge test is used to screen for gestational diabetes mellitus. Potential complications of pregestational diabetes mellitus include gestational hypertension, preeclampsia, eclampsia, urinary tract infections, and fetal diabetic fetopathy. A 1-hour glucose challenge is indicated at 24–28 weeks of gestation; this patient's normal serum β-hCG concentration indicates that she is currently not pregnant. A hemoglobin A1C test would be used to detect pregestational diabetes mellitus.

B) INCORRECT:

Group B streptococcus (GBS) infection can cause chorioamnionitis, neonatal meningitis, sepsis, and pneumonia; vaginal and rectal swab for gram stain and culture can detect GBS. However, GBS screening is indicated at 35 to 37 weeks' gestation rather than before conception.

C) CORRECT:

As part of comprehensive preconception care, physicians should assess individuals' immunization status and recommend all routine age-appropriate immunizations. Because of the risk of congenital abnormalities following infection with rubella or varicella in pregnancy, the MMR and varicella vaccines are especially recommended. In patients with no evidence of immunity to rubella (e.g., those who did not receive the MMR vaccine), rubella antibody testing should be used to screen for immunity, and vaccination should be recommended in individuals without immunity. The MMR and varicella vaccines are live vaccines, which are contraindicated during pregnancy due to the potential risk of infection in the birthing parent and consequent vertical transmission. Accordingly, conception should be avoided for 1–3 months after immunization.

In the past, administering the MMR vaccine to children with egg allergies raised concerns because of residual egg proteins in the vaccine. However, the MMR vaccine is currently considered safe for children with egg allergy.

Key learning point: Preconception care should include screening for rubella immunity with an antibody titer, as MMR vaccination is recommended before pregnancy if immunity is lacking.

D) INCORRECT:

Canada’s Food Guide recommends a daily multivitamin containing folic acid for all women of childbearing age, but iron supplementation is only recommended in pregnant individuals. In addition, this patient's complete blood count is normal, and she has no evidence of anemia. Therefore, an iron supplement is not recommended at this time.
questions.hint: This patient has a normal serum β-hCG concentration, which indicates that she is not currently pregnant. Many diseases increase the risk to the fetus and birthing parent. However, certain diseases can be devastating to the fetus and are ideally addressed prior to conception.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine examination. She recently began a new job as a middle school science teacher. The patient has no significant medical history and takes no medications. She has never traveled outside the United States, has no known drug allergies, and has never smoked or used illicit drugs. She drinks alcohol socially. The patient is sexually active with her husband and is not pregnant. Her last tetanus-containing vaccine was at age 12 years. She received all childhood vaccinations, including the full series for measles, mumps, and rubella. She had chickenpox at 7 years of age and received the human papillomavirus vaccine series in her early 20s. Her last influenza vaccine was 2 years ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate vaccination recommendation at this visit?

choices.text: Administer tetanus, diphtheria, acellular pertussis vaccine

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Routine hepatitis B immunization was implemented for all infants in the United States in 1991. This 25-year-old patient was born after universal childhood hepatitis B immunization became standard practice; therefore, she likely received the full hepatitis B vaccine series in early childhood and does not require catch-up vaccination. Hepatitis B vaccine boosters are indicated only in high-risk patients (e.g., occupational exposure, immunocompromise, those receiving hemodialysis) who are nonimmune according to HBV serology (HBsAb < 10 IU/mL).

B) INCORRECT:

Meningococcal vaccination is recommended for individuals at risk for meningococcal infections (e.g., those with asplenia or complement deficiencies, college students living in dormitories, military recruits). Middle school teachers do not require routine meningococcal vaccination unless they have other risk factors.

C) INCORRECT:

The recombinant zoster vaccine is recommended for adults ≥ 50 years of age and immunocompromised individuals ≥ 19 years of age, regardless of prior varicella infection or shingles history. This patient is only 25 years of age and is not immunocompromised, so zoster vaccination is not indicated at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Pneumococcal vaccination is indicated for individuals ≥ 50 years of age and for those aged 19–49 years with risk factors for invasive pneumococcal disease (e.g., immunocompromise, asplenia). This is a healthy 25-year-old patient with no risk factors requiring pneumococcal vaccination.

E) CORRECT:

A single dose of tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine is recommended for all adults who have not previously received it or whose last dose was in adolescence. After initial Tdap vaccination, all patients should receive tetanus-diphtheria vaccine or Tdap boosters every 10 years. This patient’s last tetanus-containing vaccine was at 12 years of age, so she is overdue for a Tdap booster. As a middle school teacher, protection against pertussis is especially important to prevent transmission to vulnerable children. Tdap also maintains immunity against diphtheria, which can cause severe illness.

Annual influenza vaccination is also recommended for all adults, including this patient, but Tdap is the most urgent vaccination in this scenario.

questions.text: An 18-year-old man presents for a routine physical examination. He will be living in a dormitory in college in the fall. His mother expresses concern about a rapidly progressive infection she heard about that can cause severe illness and death in college students. He is healthy and has no chronic medical conditions. His last childhood immunizations were administered when he was 12 years old. Which of the following is the most appropriate vaccine to administer to reduce his risk for this specific infection?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of bacterial meningitis, routine pneumococcal vaccination is recommended for all children younger than 2 years and for adults ≥ 50 years. It is not routinely indicated for healthy 18-year-old individuals without specific underlying medical conditions that increase their risk.

B) INCORRECT:

Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib) can cause meningitis, but routine childhood vaccination has made invasive Hib disease rare in adolescents and adults in the United States. This patient would have completed the primary Hib vaccine series as an infant and does not require a booster dose at this age.

C) CORRECT:

The Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices (ACIP) recommends a routine two-dose series for the quadrivalent meningococcal conjugate vaccine (MenACWY). The first dose is administered at age 11–12, and a booster dose is recommended at age 16. This patient received his primary dose at age 12 but missed the booster. The booster is crucial because immunity wanes, and the risk of meningococcal disease increases in late adolescence and early adulthood, particularly in congregate living settings like college dormitories. Therefore, administering the MenACWY booster now is the most appropriate step to protect him against serogroups A, C, W, and Y.

D) INCORRECT:

The tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine is routinely recommended for adolescents at age 11–12. A tetanus and diphtheria booster is recommended every 10 years thereafter to maintain protection against tetanus and diphtheria. This patient's next booster is due at age 22. Additionally, for an 18-year-old preparing to enter college, another vaccine is more appropriate.
questions.hint: The routine vaccination schedule for the infection described involves a primary dose at age 11–12 and a booster dose at age 16 to ensure protection during the high-risk college years.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old girl presents to the Outpatient Clinic for a routine exam. Her immunization records show she received her first varicella vaccine at 14 months but missed her second dose, which is recommended at 4–6 years of age. She has no history of varicella infection. Her mother is concerned about upcoming travel where exposures might be more likely. Physical examination is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to ensure she has adequate protection against varicella?

choices.text: Wait until she is at least 11 years old for the second dose
Administer the second varicella vaccine now

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Delaying the second varicella dose until age 11 contradicts guidelines, which recommend the second dose between 4 and 6 years. The child is already 8 years old and at risk of exposure due to travel. Timely completion of the vaccine series is essential for adequate protection.

B) INCORRECT:

Obtaining varicella immunoglobulin G (IgG) titers is not recommended for assessing immunity in this healthy child. Current guidelines advise completing the two-dose series for adequate protection. Serologic testing is not routinely reliable for vaccine-derived immunity due to variability in assay sensitivity and lack of standardized protective thresholds.

C) INCORRECT:

Restarting the varicella immunization series is unnecessary. The patient has a documented valid first dose. Guidelines state that only the missing second dose is needed to complete the series, enhancing protection without restarting the series.

D) CORRECT:

The varicella vaccination schedule includes an initial dose in early childhood and a booster between 4 and 6 years of age. This patient received the first dose but missed the booster. Administering the second dose now is recommended to enhance immunity, especially with upcoming travel increasing exposure risk. The booster significantly boosts long-term immunity, reducing the risk of varicella infection and complications. Current guidelines emphasize administering the booster as soon as it is identified as missed, ensuring adequate protection even if the recommended age interval has passed.

Key learning point: If the second dose of a varicella vaccination is missed, it should be administered as soon as possible to complete the series and achieve full immunity.

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of involuntary muscle contractions and pain in his back and neck. Two weeks ago, he fell while playing in the sandbox and scraped his knees. He has not received any vaccinations since birth. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). He is diaphoretic. Examination shows inability to open his mouth beyond 1 cm. There is hyperextension of the lumbar spine and resistance to neck flexion. Administration of which of the following would most likely have prevented this patient's current condition?

choices.text: Human immunoglobulin against a viral protein

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Capsular polysaccharide vaccines contain purified capsule antigens that are usually conjugated to a carrier protein (conjugate vaccine). Such vaccines are used to prevent infection with, e.g., S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae type b, and N. meningitidis, all of which can cause meningitis. Although meningitis can present with fever and neck stiffness, trismus and opisthotonus are not characteristic features. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.

B) INCORRECT:

Chemically-inactivated (whole-cell) viruses have been used as vaccines to prevent, e.g., polio (Salk vaccine), hepatitis A, and influenza virus infections. However, this patient presents with symptoms of tetanus. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.

C) CORRECT:

Denatured C. tetani toxoid is used as a vaccination against tetanus. The still-intact receptor binding site of the toxoid induces antibody production and memory cell formation (active immunity). In patients with dirty wounds and incomplete or unclear tetanus immunization status, postexposure prophylaxis should include vaccination with DTaP and administration of human tetanus immunoglobulin (HTIG). Management of tetanus includes antibiotic therapy and intensive care treatment.
Image Description:

This diagram illustrates vaccine types based on the example of antiviral vaccines.

Traditional vaccines are either live attenuated or inactivated. Live attenuated vaccines contain modified whole virus particles capable of replication, but not of causing disease. Inactivated vaccines contain either the whole inactivated virus particles or their subunits.

Gene-based vaccines contain only the genetic information of the pathogen. This information, which is transmitted either directly in the form of nucleic acid (DNA in a recombinant plasmid or mRNA in a lipid envelope) or by means of a recombinant viral vector, induces endogenous antigen production in the host cells.

D) INCORRECT:

Human immunoglobulin against a viral protein is used for post-exposure prophylaxis in suspected cases of rabies. Administering preformed antibodies provides a passive immunity that, however, does not last long due to the antibodies' short half-life. Even though patients with rabies can present with trismus, opisthotonus, and symptoms of autonomic hyperactivity, as seen in this patient, they also present with other characteristic features like hydrophobia and agitation. Furthermore, this patient has no history of an animal bite (e.g., by a bat or raccoon) that would raise suspicion for transmission of rabies. In post-exposure prophylaxis of tetanus, which is caused by a bacterium, not a virus, human tetanus immunoglobulin (TIG) is used against tetanus toxin.

E) INCORRECT:

Viable but weakened microorganisms are used in live attenuated vaccines for the prevention of, e.g., measles, mumps, rubella, varicella zoster, and rotavirus infection. These vaccines induce both cellular and humoral immune responses. However, this patient presents with symptoms of tetanus. Tetanus vaccination uses another means of immunization.
questions.hint: Generalized muscle spasms (trismus, mild opisthotonus, nuchal rigidity) and symptoms of autonomic hyperactivity (fever, sweating) following a cutaneous injury in an unvaccinated child suggest tetanus, which is diagnosed clinically.
